number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 3, 2016
												Tags : Isometric RPG - Post Apocalyptic*HALL OF FAME* *ALL-TIME FAVORITES*Heavily inspired by Pen and Paper. Gritty, well designed, solid dialogue, effective turn based combat. This can be a hard game, and you can seriously develop your character into a corner, or have a savegame that can no longer be salvaged and you will have to restart the game if you want to win the main mission. The requirements not to fail the main arc have been heavily relaxed through patching but I personally miss the classic difficulty of version 1.0. Game has been remastered somewhat to work on modern OS with modern resolutions and can be slightly modded by looking for files on the "no mutants allowed" forums. It can be necessary nowadays to modify the variable for random encounters in the desert as without them you do not level your combat oriented character nearly enough while travelling, and the amount of random encounters decreases as a function of CPU power, the higher the CPU the faster you travel the less encounters you face, it is strange but that is the way it is coded. This game among with others of its kind has gotten me hooked the isometric perspective and I personally love the work that went into the animations. The character models are reused heaviliy throuought the game however, but there is a fair amount of variety in tiles for locations so you do not always run into the same kind of maps. There is no procedural generation here everything was handcrafted.A masterpiece in my humble opinion and one that sets a personal standard for what a RPG is, your character and your choices will influence the play experience quite a lot here.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
												This game is legendarily great. The gameplay and story are compelling, but the world is the real star of the show here. That, and Harold and Dogmeat. They're stars too.Tips for companions:Dogmeat is a machine. Doesn't do much damage, but moves ridiculous distances, attacks 4 times a round, knocks enemies down all over the place so that you can 95% critical their eyes, and, most importantly, is the emotional heart of the story. I kept him alive all the way.Tycho is great. He's smart, durable, and funny. Just keep him stocked with shotgun shells and Stimpaks and he'll never let you down. Unfortunately, he died in the Cathedral.Ian is a staple for the first part of the game, but by the time you get power armor he's basically obsolete. I let him go eventually.Katja can mark the Cathedral on your map. That's about it. I made the mistake of giving her an SMG, and eventually abandoned her along with Ian. Hopefully they're fine in the middle of the desert.P.S. The gory death animations are fine, but the fact that they're used as rewards for winning makes them that much more priceless.P.P.S. I accidentally dropped Vree's holodisk moments after getting it in the Brotherhood base, later realized how important it is, went back, and, months later, it was still there. The Brotherhood really needs a janitor.

content:
Posted: August 16, 2015
												Highly recommend, for any Fallout fan especially. But if you are not a big fan of Fallout, purchase with caution! This game has shown to be unpopular among people such as my friends. But if you're looking for a new post-apocolypse game, from a interesting old-timey prespective in the sky to play, I'd say give it a try!The game is amazing. A real great start to what would become the franchise of Fallout. There are many bugs like with any game, and in my opinion, this game is unfinished in vanilla version. With ending scripts and such not working, quests being non-avaible that break a players potentally desired choices, yadda yadda ... And I believe it was said because of time restraints. Which was sad, that they couldn't fix all this first.So because of these reasons, I point people toward looking up the mod "Fallout Fixt" which fixes basically all of this. A super mod that really re-added that kick in the game for me, after finishing it vanilla wise. Making it more so how it was expected to be played, and should be played. Though don't forget to play vanilla first alone, to see what I mean. Even adds a few other goodies too, which makes it all that sweeter. I consider this mod an essential part of the game when I play it now, you could say.Cough And between you and me, this may just be my favorite Fallout with the mod!

Fallout: A Post Nuclear Role Playing GameFallout is a pure classic.Without going into any deeper debate, it was one of the first "open-world" RPGs that hit the western market.Even in 2014 it's a solid game, if you can forgive its aged graphics, shallow mainstory and sometimes frustrating controls.One could burrow down in a review and dig in the past, praising the game for what it was, when it was released.I'll just make it short and say "It was outstanding!".In todays game market, it falls flat on it's nose for the story. But it's the side quests that makes Fallout such a good game. If you just run main story.. First of all, it's gonna be HARD! Secondly, you'll miss out on what makes Fallout so great.I give Fallout 7/10 kittens.The main thing that bugs me is the controls, but for a game being almost 20 years old.. It still rocks!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 8, 2015
												This game did something only one other 90's game did for me (Half-Life). It took a genre that we know and love today, and redefines it. This game is one of the best, if not THE best RPG I've ever played.+ Amazing atmosphere+ A great amount of detail. Every place feels hand crafted, and polished+ S.P.E.C.I.A.L. is a creative way to create your character, rather than making cosmetic changes that RPG's do today+ Pure freedom is encouraged. Fallout 3 and New Vegas are good games, but I believe the first gives the most freedom.+ A few very different, creative, and even horrifying alternative endings+ Great soundtrack, accompanied by The Ink Spots, my favorite 30's-40's band!+ A large amount of enemies. From mutants, to raiders, radscorpions, rats, and tons more+ A great amount of weapons as well. Trust me though, energy weapons are your friend. Remember that while playing.+ Different ways to approach about any mission+ Great final "Boss" with 3 different ways to deal with him. No spoilers, sorry+ Writing is alright, surprisingly! A mix of serious and funny! "Moo, I say!" -Brahmin+ Although there aren't a whole ton of locations like in F3, and FNV, these locations are huge and branched out.+ You can actually join different factions, rather than sitting next to them feeling like a sidekick. In F3, you helped the Brotherhood of Steel. In F1, you straight up join them!+ Interesting characters all over the world+ Followers that can help you on your quest. Remember, their death is permanent!+ The animation in the game is surprisingly good! The cutscenes are amazing as well, especially for it's time.+ The story seems so simple. "Go get a water chip" is the beggining, but it eventually branches out and has a good amount of lore in it as well+ Rather than helping someone in the Crimson Caravan find love (Fallout New Vegas), you actually get to join up with the caravan and make a good amount of caps from it, too+ A good 14 Hours long from what I've played. This is the longest 90's game I've ever played that kept me entertained the whole time+/- You can accidentally shoot your partners. Although it may only happen a few times for you, it will happen a lot with your partners shooting you.- A bit of an anticlimax "Good Ending", which is the one I got. Again, no spoilers- A few bugs, too. I can still ask for a water purification chip even though I found it a year ago- The shown chance of hitting a target is a bit off sometimes. "95% chance to hit this rat twice!? I got thi... I missed both times..."9.5/10 An Outstanding TitleThis is a prime example of what RPG's should be. True freedom to do just about anything, anytime. If you're getting Fallout 1 & 2, just buy the Classic Collection. You'll get Fallout Tactics: Brotherhood of Steel along with Fallout 1 & 2 (3 games for the price of 2). Well, off to Fallout 2! Wish me luck!

content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
												Let me begin by saying i have played every fallout game to date.Fallout is a Open World Post Nuclear Role Playing Game, Which Is Set 80 Years after the Nuclear War which nearly brought an end to mankind there were a few lucky survivors who were able to enter these giant underground Vault's on the day that the bombs dropped, you were born in Vault 13.The Main Story Plot of Fallout is that Your Vaults Water Purification Chip has Broken and that means that The Vault will run out of drinking water very soon so the Vault's Overseer Send's you the Vault Dweller out on a Quest to find a replacement Water Chip.Gameplay in Fallout centers around the game world, visiting locations and interacting with the local inhabitants. Occasionally, inhabitants will be immersed in dilemmas which the player may choose to solve in order to acquire karma and experience points. Fallout deviates from most role-playing video games in that it often allows for the player to complete tasks in multiple ways, often choosing solutions that are unconventional or even contrary to the original task, in which case the player may still be rewarded. The player's actions may ultimately dictate the ending of the game, or what future story or gameplay opportunities are available. Ultimately, players will encounter hostile opponents (if such encounters are not avoided using stealth or diplomacy), in which case they and the player will engage in combat. Non-combat portions of the game are typically played in real-time.Combat in Fallout is turn-based. The game uses an action point system wherein, each turn, multiple actions may be performed until all points in the pool have been expended. Different actions consume different numbers of points, and the maximum number of points that can be spent may be affected by such things as chems or perks. 'Melee' (hand to hand) weapons typically offer multiple attack types, such as 'Swing' and 'Thrust' for knives. Unarmed attacks offer many attack types, including 'Punch' and 'Kick'. Players may equip at most two weapons, and the player can switch between them by clicking a button. The Perception attribute determines characters' 'Sequence' number, which then determines the order of turns in combat; characters with a higher statistic in this attribute will be placed at an earlier position in the sequence of turns, and subsequently get new turns earlier. Perception also determines the maximum range of ranged weapons, and the chance to hit with them.I Would Recomend Fallout To any fan of the Series Or Newcomer.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 8, 2015
												This game did something only one other 90's game did for me (Half-Life). It took a genre that we know and love today, and redefines it. This game is one of the best, if not THE best RPG I've ever played.+ Amazing atmosphere+ A great amount of detail. Every place feels hand crafted, and polished+ S.P.E.C.I.A.L. is a creative way to create your character, rather than making cosmetic changes that RPG's do today+ Pure freedom is encouraged. Fallout 3 and New Vegas are good games, but I believe the first gives the most freedom.+ A few very different, creative, and even horrifying alternative endings+ Great soundtrack, accompanied by The Ink Spots, my favorite 30's-40's band!+ A large amount of enemies. From mutants, to raiders, radscorpions, rats, and tons more+ A great amount of weapons as well. Trust me though, energy weapons are your friend. Remember that while playing.+ Different ways to approach about any mission+ Great final "Boss" with 3 different ways to deal with him. No spoilers, sorry+ Writing is alright, surprisingly! A mix of serious and funny! "Moo, I say!" -Brahmin+ Although there aren't a whole ton of locations like in F3, and FNV, these locations are huge and branched out.+ You can actually join different factions, rather than sitting next to them feeling like a sidekick. In F3, you helped the Brotherhood of Steel. In F1, you straight up join them!+ Interesting characters all over the world+ Followers that can help you on your quest. Remember, their death is permanent!+ The animation in the game is surprisingly good! The cutscenes are amazing as well, especially for it's time.+ The story seems so simple. "Go get a water chip" is the beggining, but it eventually branches out and has a good amount of lore in it as well+ Rather than helping someone in the Crimson Caravan find love (Fallout New Vegas), you actually get to join up with the caravan and make a good amount of caps from it, too+ A good 14 Hours long from what I've played. This is the longest 90's game I've ever played that kept me entertained the whole time+/- You can accidentally shoot your partners. Although it may only happen a few times for you, it will happen a lot with your partners shooting you.- A bit of an anticlimax "Good Ending", which is the one I got. Again, no spoilers- A few bugs, too. I can still ask for a water purification chip even though I found it a year ago- The shown chance of hitting a target is a bit off sometimes. "95% chance to hit this rat twice!? I got thi... I missed both times..."9.5/10 An Outstanding TitleThis is a prime example of what RPG's should be. True freedom to do just about anything, anytime. If you're getting Fallout 1 & 2, just buy the Classic Collection. You'll get Fallout Tactics: Brotherhood of Steel along with Fallout 1 & 2 (3 games for the price of 2). Well, off to Fallout 2! Wish me luck!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5, 2014
												10/10 - A shining pinnacle of human achievement.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------GRAPHICS --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------First off, graphics aren't everything to me. I grew up with Atari, Apple ][e, PowerMacs, NES, and so on. Fallout uses the good old 800x600 overhead isometric view, and does it quite right. The game has a fair amount of variety in the appearance of the locations, though the "cave" areas tend to get a bit too familiar. There is a ton of variety in the objects used, and a lot of areas are just really nice art to look at. It holds up for me, personally. Objectively, it looked great when it came out, but was kind of bashed a bit for not being a light sourced 3D game. Those were the expectations of the time.The best part about the various character models in the game is the way that they are torn apart, melted, disintegrated, exploded and otherwise ended when you discharge your fury on them. The flamethrower is good for laughs, especially. It certainly followed through on the vision of its spiritual predecessor, Wasteland, in that respect. The dialouge sequences with certain characters brings you to a great looking 3D model of the character's animated head, but other wise all characters are rather small and faceless.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------SOUND ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------The music, combined with the graphics, creates a thick, perfect layer of atmosphere. The desolation and tension of this setting really is emphasized by the great music. Composer Mark Morgan totally nailed it. The various gunshots, laser beams, rockets and explosions of combat all sound great. The 10mm Handgun especially has a very satisfying "THUD" to it.The voice acting is frigging phenominal. Frank Welker, Ron Perlman, Tony Shalhoub, Tress MacNeille, and a bunch more take care of voicing the metric ton of dialouge that exists for all cut scenes and plot "essential" characters. It all sounds so good, you will want to have the sound and music turned up nice and loud while you play. Really, really good.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------GAMEPLAY -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Movement while exploring is similar to Diablo, point and click to go. When combat starts, the game switches to turn based mode. This is where how you build your skills and equip your character matters more than how fast you can click on different things. It is possible to gimp your character, and die repeatedly if you don't pay attention to some basic survival needs. Such as at least one strong combat skill, and average intelligence at the very barest of minimums. Intelligence is responsible for getting more points to put into skills when you level up. One or more of your various skills is going to determine your success in pretty much everything you can do in this game. Speech can be a path netting some extra information and reward often enough that I find it useful too. At least a smattering of everything will come in handy, but I personally wouldn't go without lockpick, medicine (for healing and for quests), and science. For combat, anything will do, but bear two things in mind. Be the best. Choose one of the various combat skills, and pump points into it every level until it is at least 75. Then keep rasing it, but it isn't so much of a priority compared to diversity at that point. Smal guns are the most widely available, but don't let that keep you from choosing your own path as they are all viable. It is possible to "play the bad guy" and destroy your karmaic reputation in order to steal, murder, and otherwise plunder the shambles of a society that remains on Earth. Indeed, some quests and items are most easily and quickly performed by stealing something, or locking the door and murdering someone. But, your karma follows you around in this game. At a certain point, you will be unwelcome. Then, people might want to kill you for what you have done. I find that the path of the righteous leads to far greater reward in terms of XP, in this game. There is a wide variety of weapons, armor, enemies, and locations for battle. The battles can play out rather slowly, and being turn based are not everyone's cup of whatever. The game can be rather challenging at the start if you aren't used to these sorts of games, but the difficulty can be changed at any time in game. The game is kind of equal parts combat and exploration. There is a great deal of humor in both, and I have spent plenty of time just watching random NPC's interact with each other. It all piles on to the atmosphere of the fledgling civilization struggling to survive in the harsh new hell they created, only to be found repeating the same death spiral pattern of behaviors that set them on the path in the first place.If you aren't immediately turned off by the graphics and the turn based nature of the game play, then this game might be for you. It is one of the precursors to such games as the Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale serieseses.. es. Planescape Torment. Shares team members with Knights of The Old Republic 1 and 2, Fallout New Vegas, Arcanum, and a few more greatest role playing games ever. (KOTOR 2 and Greyhawk have at least been fixed and patched to greatness on PC...) But Fallout and Fallout 2 have always been my very favorites and the most replayed. If you dig a little, you will find that there is a ton of depth and character in this rather slow paced old school game.(Never you mind what the "hours played" on Steam says, my Steam was mostly offline for intermittent years. When I played the game for hundreds of hours since its release, it was the CD-rom version.)

												One of the best games I have ever played and was surprised to see that it didn't have 99% for positive reviews. So naturally I checked them and can confirm that roughly every negative review was from some retard who didn't so much as look at screenshots, doesn't have any patience whatsoever (I dont even know how you could need patience for this game but people said it was to slow???), and failed to try and even understand how to play the game. Example being "I can never hit anything" Most likely but everything into melee and tried to make eye shots with a gun completely ignoring the % chances to hit specific areas. Normally I would suggest looking at negative reviews because they can point out some huge drawbacks in the game that might make you want to rethink buying it, but in this case they are all pretty much written by ADHD children who wanted a first person shooter (again not a single look at the screenshots).  The only decent one was the top voted one that talked about how this is "slightly" censored and you cant kill children, which I agree is complete bull... You probably want to play with the Fixt mod for this game, basically its a giant patch, doesnt really add anything and the few things it does add are entirely optional. (psst with this you can make your companions move the ♥♥♥♥ out of the door finally). If you truly want to see the game for what it is and get a good idea watch some youtube videos of this game, it is a popular game and has many HD videos with/without clear commentary.Side note: Also dont judge the positive reviews based on time, because with that patch along with the one for fallout 2 you load the game diferently and it doesn't go through steam. Hence fewer hours being shown.

												So one day i bought FALLOUT  and i had already played 3 and new vegas before that, and i had no expirence with turn-based bird-view RPGS, so it was really hard to get into this game and i was almost to the point with saying F this game.But i kept playing and now I F*****G LOVE THIS GAME <3 <3 <3 <3 <3.So first of all the story:So the story is quite simple you are from a working vault called Vault 13, but suddenly the Overseer(king of the vault)says that we are running out of drinking water and he wants you to find them a waterchip to fix thier problem. The waterchip is used to fix up radiated water.One thing i really love about this game is that you can complete all the main quests without any help or given locations.Like for example one girl actually knows where to find the waterchip and it is in a place that you could get a holodisk to find or you could just travel around the wasteland until you find it.another thing is that the water quest is actually timed so you have about 120 days to find it or else you loose the game!! So now i will give  pros and cons about ths gamePROS-gameplay that works-great story-pretty good graphics- talking like a retard with low intellgence skill-TOO AWESOME-can be played on pretty much any computer-CONS-no journal, what i mean by that is that i tried doing a quest for someone and he said something about go west then south when you find this place and then kill them, but i completely forgot where to go and he didn't mention it again so i either had to remember it or write down on a piece of paper, it's not a big deal but i didn't like it :(-too short dunno man i just wanted more.-MY OPINION i only thought this game was awesome when i had good guns and protection, but that's just me and not really a con but i had to mention it.-No freeplay after main quests, this really sucks if you have unfinished side quests that play a big role but actually in the end the narroter tells about what happend to ceartain places if you didn't help them which is really cool ;DSO overall i think that this is one  of the best RPGS ever made even though i'm not a hardocre RPG'r,i will say that this is proabaly one of the best games that i ever played in my life, AND i cannot wait to play fallout 2 i'll just wait for a discount though.OKAY I'VE TALKED ENOUGH THIS GAME GET'S A 8.9/10

content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												Where it all started, Fallout. Before Bethesda got the rights to the Fallout series and gave us the wonders of Fallout 3, New Vegas, and 4, Fallout was owned by Interplay and Black Isle studios. The classic Fallout games (1-tactics) were isometric turn based rpgs with a heavy open world exploration aspect to them. Now, jumping away from the history lesson and back to the game at hand. Fallout is a gritty, post apocolyptic rpg set after a nuclear war. And it really shows, raiders, super mutuants, anything in this wastland can be a friend or most likely a foe. The game can be very diffucult if you don't know what to expect. Everything you encounter, from cave rats to the brotherhood of steel, can kill you. Here's some spoilers, so don't touch if you don't want the story ruined. Ready? Alright.  You're tasked by the overseer of vault 13 to find a new water chip for the vault, as the one they have has died and water is running low. Setting off into a cave and the huge wastes, you must find a water chip and destroy the ever looming threat of the supermutant army, led by the Master. Once you complete these tasks in any order you please, you return to the vault you just saved....only to be banished.  If you're looking for a long, difficult at times, classic rpg, you should turn to the classic Fallout series. A definite must buy for any rpg fan.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
												Fallout is possibly the first game to have a wide variety of choices and consequences. (and perks/traits.) And it shouldn't be played just because it's the first to do it, but because it does it very well.It starts with a simple premise: You live in an underground nuclear fallout shelter (aka, a Vault) 80 years after a two-hour war between China and the US basically ended up in the both countries getting wholly nuked, and the water chip that keeps a supply of water to the whole Vault was damaged, and you were the unlucky one to have to venture out into the outside world to find the closest Vault and get another chip to save everyone you know. You are expelled into a cave full of rats (the ultimate and classic RPG enemy) and have to venture out, the first of your Vault to do so.Fallout's system, SPECIAL, was made in a week (with the exception of perks), and it shows. The original goal of the team, when the game still had a license for GURPS (another system) was that no skill or stat should be useless. Well, first tip to creating a character: dump Charisma and get 4 free stat points. There are also a lot of mostly useless skills, but anyone with half a brain should distinguish the useless from the useful.Combat is nothing special, except for the gory death animations: When getting crits with different weapons, enemies (or you) will die in very elaborate deaths: getting cut in half by the sheer amount of bullet holes a burst fire of a mini-gun has gave you, for example! It's pretty fun, even though the combat itself lacks tactical depth (sure, you can aim at limbs, eyes and crotch, but you'll end up shooting eyes always - well, maybe crotch for some amusing banter :))It's not a very long game, but throughout it you venture through several settlements that have been built   by the surivivors of California. You will have several multi-pathed quests and consequences, though, sadly, most of the consequences are only showed in the slideshow at the end of the game. Still, you will feel that your choices matter. The atmosphere is great, with no small influence of the great ambient soundtrack Mark Morgan produced, and the game gets better the more you progress into it: The final two areas have the most different ways of approaching the obstacles presented, and the game ends with one of the best ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ "final bosses" of game history, if you choose to not kill him directly: You talk him out of doing spoiler , but your speech skill won't do it alone. You'll have to find evidence that convinces him. And then, you will be shown what you could and couldn't do. On the first playthrough, unless you got lucky, you will end up having failed to save a lot of people.Well, how about a replay?

And it shouldn't be played just because it's the first to do it, but because it does it very well.It starts with a simple premise: You live in an underground nuclear fallout shelter (aka, a Vault) 80 years after a two-hour war between China and the US basically ended up in the both countries getting wholly nuked, and the water chip that keeps a supply of water to the whole Vault was damaged, and you were the unlucky one to have to venture out into the outside world to find the closest Vault and get another chip to save everyone you know. You are expelled into a cave full of rats (the ultimate and classic RPG enemy) and have to venture out, the first of your Vault to do so.Fallout's system, SPECIAL, was made in a week (with the exception of perks), and it shows. The original goal of the team, when the game still had a license for GURPS (another system) was that no skill or stat should be useless. Well, first tip to creating a character: dump Charisma and get 4 free stat points. There are also a lot of mostly useless skills, but anyone with half a brain should distinguish the useless from the useful.Combat is nothing special, except for the gory death animations: When getting crits with different weapons, enemies (or you) will die in very elaborate deaths: getting cut in half by the sheer amount of bullet holes a burst fire of a mini-gun has gave you, for example! It's pretty fun, even though the combat itself lacks tactical depth (sure, you can aim at limbs, eyes and crotch, but you'll end up shooting eyes always - well, maybe crotch for some amusing banter :))It's not a very long game, but throughout it you venture through several settlements that have been built   by the surivivors of California. You will have several multi-pathed quests and consequences, though, sadly, most of the consequences are only showed in the slideshow at the end of the game. Still, you will feel that your choices matter. The atmosphere is great, with no small influence of the great ambient soundtrack Mark Morgan produced, and the game gets better the more you progress into it: The final two areas have the most different ways of approaching the obstacles presented, and the game ends with one of the best ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ "final bosses" of game history, if you choose to not kill him directly: You talk him out of doing spoiler , but your speech skill won't do it alone. You'll have to find evidence that convinces him. And then, you will be shown what you could and couldn't do. On the first playthrough, unless you got lucky, you will end up having failed to save a lot of people.Well, how about a replay?

content:
Posted: April 19
Simple Review: Fallout: A Post Nuclear Role Playing GameThe original Fallout.  A true masterpiece in many regards.  The story is very good from start to finish. and will be something that you won't forget.  As a player you're put under a lot of pressure throughout the story, but are given just enough oppurtunities to succeed.  The characters are well written and all have distinct personalities.  Characters in the game have integrity and interacting with them can bring rewards but also many consequences, and it feels just right.  The environments are superbly done graphically for the time, and are also very detailed.  Every place that you visit during the game can tell its own story through the art and flavor text from examining objects.  The roleplaying experience is almost perfect, allowing you do create virtually any kind of post-apocalyptic survivor imaginable.  The game also gives you at least two if not more ways to approach every quest in the game, so playing can suit the character that you've created.  The gameplay through combat and interacting with the environment however aren't done nearly as well as the rest of the game.  The combat is unbalanced, favoring certain weapon types heavily over others at various points in the game, while practically neglecting a whole weapon type for the entire game up until the final few of hours of play time.  Many skills that have to do with environmental puzzles are almost entirely useless and are only applicable in a few areas of the game,  with one skill being (for all intents and purposes) completely useless throughout the whole game.  Despite these setbacks the other areas of the game more than make up for it all, and will end up delivering a remarkable experience.  If you like turn-based role playing games from the golden era of PC gaming, this should be a no brainer.  For everybody else I would still highly recommend this game.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												+Great game, lotta fun once you figure out the combat system+Learn a lot about the Fallout universe that you wouldn't know from only playing 3 or New Vegas, such as what happened at other Vaults, the origins of things like super-mutants and Raiders+Awesome weapons+Turn-based combat is tough and always keeps you on your toes+Enemies are scarier as a result+As far as I know, you can't become an invincible god like in 3 and New Vegas which gives you a sense of humility+Which also forces you to fight cautiously, strategically and pick your battles+Random events are either positive or negative so you're hopeful, yet cautious when traveling+In-game time is important, which gives a sense of immersion+In-game time isn't too fast or too slow, it's just right+It also goes into much more vivid detail than most games, there's an in-game calendar and things happen on certain dates, most games do night/day like , occasionally you'll see a game that does time of the day or day of the week+No fast traveling like in 3 or New Vegas. Instead of pulling up your Pip Boy and selecting a place, you have to actually leave your current city, then travel to the next. You're shown a map of the whole area and once you click somewhere, your guy moves as in-game time flies by at a realistic and believable pace. You also slow down at mountains and stuff, to make it seem more like you're climbing them. Occasionally, you get a random event which stops your traveling and gives you more of a feeling like your actually adventuring-Combat system is hard to get used to-Enemies can be a bit too tough at times-If there are too many enemies, you're going to die, no matter how much skill or luck you possess-If there are enough NPCs during a battle, you have to wait forever for your turn as each NPC moves and attacks one at a time, especially during missions where you help escort the Crimson Caravan-During such battle, I bet I could walk away from my computer, make a sandwich, and come back and still be waiting for my turn-Turn based combat is annoying and confusing before you learn how it works, which is not easy because it isn't self-explanatory in any way+/- Even though it's Fallout, it has a completely different feel if you're like most Fallout players if you've only played 3 or New Vegas. I like this fact, but I can imagine that others wouldn't+/- Neurtal NPCs react to you unholstering your weapon. From a realism point of view, it makes sense, but from a gameplay point of view, it can be annoying

content:
Posted: November 21, 2013
												“The struggle for survival is a war without end. And war… war never changes.”Fallout is one of those rare role-playing games oozing quality from every pore – one might even say radiate. The gameplay is smooth, using action points for movement and combat. In addition it has one of the best character development systems you can wish for. The amazing story, great love for detail and high replayability make for an excellent gaming experience.Fun fact: Fallouts retro-futurism has been inspired by 1950s pulp magazines, superhero comics of Atomic Age and classic Science Fiction films such as Forbidden Planet. There are also many references to the events and the style of Wasteland (PC game from 1988) in the Fallout series, which is why Fallout is sometimes regarded as a spiritual successor to Wasteland.--My rating system consists of six categories in descending order of importance:-	Atmosphere-	Characters-	Details-	Tactical gameplay-	Story-	Combat & ControlsBased on the performance each category will receive one of the following grading: -	S-Rank: excellent-	A-Rank: very good-	B-Rank: solid-	C-Rank: satisfactory-	D-Rank: inferiorIf the S-Rank is awarded, a quote from the game or personal comment will be added as a token of my respect (in brackets).--Atmosphere: S-Rank(I am the bringer of death! Fall to your knees and beg for mercy… or give me a sandwich, I’m pretty hungry.)Characters: S-Rank (Do I have to sacrifice a puppy to join?)Details: S-Rank (To see a valley filled with my enemies’ heads mounted on spears. A silent valley, except for the wind whistling through their ears.)Tactical gameplay: S-Rank (Don’t drink glowing water.)Story: S-Rank (There is a bad place where the bad mutants come from. It is bad. Vault is good. Please, go and destroy bad place.)Combat & Controls: S-Rank (Excuse me while I gloat…)--There are no achievements to conquer.Achievement difficulty: none--Fallout: New Vegas (PC) – Action role-playing game (Post-apocalyptic Science Fiction) – 2010 -Fallout 3 (PC) – Action role-playing game (Post-apocalyptic Science Fiction) – 2008-Fallout Tactics: Brotherhood of Steel (PC) – Squad-based strategy game (Post-apocalyptic Science Fiction) – 2001http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561197968514473/recommended/38420/-Fallout 2 (PC) – Turn-based role-playing game (Post-apocalyptic Science Fiction) – 1998http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561197968514473/recommended/38410/-Fallout 1 (PC) – Turn-based role-playing game (Post-apocalyptic Science Fiction) – 1997

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												One of the best RPGs ever created, and the first game in one of the greatest game series of all time. If you're a fan of Fallout 3 or Fallout: New Vegas, you need to play Fallout & Fallout 2. If you're a fan of RPGs, you need to play Fallout, if you're a fan of original, immersive, interesting, and amusing games with interesting characters, quests, worlds, and items, you need to play Fallout. The biggest complaint I hear people give Fallout and Fallout 2 is that they're "outdated" and that they've aged terribly, when this simply isn't the case. And what's worse, is that I hear this from people who supposedly claim to be HUGE Fallout fans. Fallout: New Vegas is my favorite Fallout game becuase it combines the skillful writing, RPG elements, and interesting characters and places from Fallout and Fallout 2, AND the first/third-person 3D open-world that I am used to, but even then I'm still able to turn off my FPS fanboy goggles for a little while to play an Isometric turn-based RPG because I love Fallout. I just really can't understand, if you really love Fallout, how any of the supposedly "outdated" elements of the original two games can hinder you from enjoying them, grow a pair and play them, It's not that difficult.Compared to Fallout 2, Fallout is probably a little lacking, as Fallout 2 practically improves in every single aspect of the game, a larger game world with more quests, more people to meet and more places to explore, however, the only thing FO2 doesn't really improve upon was the somewhat "serious" tone in the original, as Fallout 2 makes Fallout look like Heavy Rain in comparison. Although I myself prefer Fallout 2 for the reasons listed above, the original is still one of the greatest RPGs of all time, and of course, the forerunner for the complete Fallout series, which, for good or bad, is still going strong today. Also, don't give Ian the SMG.R.I.P. Ian, died while rescuing Tandi from the Raiders.R.I.P. Tycho, died while cleansing the Deathclaws from the Warehouse.R.I.P. Dogmeat, died while eradicating the Super Mutants from the Watershed.R.I.P. Katja, died while fighting the Super Mutants in the LA Vault.PS, game can actually run on Windows 7, *cough* Fallout 3 *cough*

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10, 2014
												I have already played this game via buying a soldout software collection. I spent many hours playing this game and I admit I needed a walkthrough as the difficulty of this game is based on you have a limited number of days, based on the storyline.The Story: For those who don't know, you start out as a vault dweller whose parents took shelter in vault 13 along with many others to avoid the coming nucular missiles at the height of World War 3. The residents are meant to stay in the vault until such a time as the raditation levels have gone down low enough as to not be a issue, however your vault's water chip has broken. The main source of drinking water based on a recycling system in the vault. As they have no other option, they need to send out one of the residents and you volunteer to enter a world that has completely changed since your ancestors walked the surface during the war and find a new water chip as the Overseer knows of a nearby vault (Vault 15) which may have a spare chip to use.The combat system is turn-based and on a invisible hex-grid. It is also based on Action Points and in combat uses what was called the VATS system where you can aim for a specific point on the creature, but if you were to take the trait that lets you shoot more often (forgot it's name) you will be unable to do accurate aiming. It's a old-school PC RPG where your decisions are totally up to you and ethics are optional in how you get the waterchip or where from. With multiple endings and detailed tellings of what happened to the places you visited, after you left leaves the game open for many multiple play throughts  for endless gameplay and always discover new things and easter eggs such as "the holy hand grenade." and other references too numerous to count.A brilliant game and well worth a purchas if you are after a old-school RPG, but as it is so old and not altered for modern systems (unlike on GoG) you will need to look up how to run the game without weird graphical glitches.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												One of the best RPGs ever created, and the first game in one of the greatest game series of all time. If you're a fan of Fallout 3 or Fallout: New Vegas, you need to play Fallout & Fallout 2. If you're a fan of RPGs, you need to play Fallout, if you're a fan of original, immersive, interesting, and amusing games with interesting characters, quests, worlds, and items, you need to play Fallout. The biggest complaint I hear people give Fallout and Fallout 2 is that they're "outdated" and that they've aged terribly, when this simply isn't the case. And what's worse, is that I hear this from people who supposedly claim to be HUGE Fallout fans. Fallout: New Vegas is my favorite Fallout game becuase it combines the skillful writing, RPG elements, and interesting characters and places from Fallout and Fallout 2, AND the first/third-person 3D open-world that I am used to, but even then I'm still able to turn off my FPS fanboy goggles for a little while to play an Isometric turn-based RPG because I love Fallout. I just really can't understand, if you really love Fallout, how any of the supposedly "outdated" elements of the original two games can hinder you from enjoying them, grow a pair and play them, It's not that difficult.Compared to Fallout 2, Fallout is probably a little lacking, as Fallout 2 practically improves in every single aspect of the game, a larger game world with more quests, more people to meet and more places to explore, however, the only thing FO2 doesn't really improve upon was the somewhat "serious" tone in the original, as Fallout 2 makes Fallout look like Heavy Rain in comparison. Although I myself prefer Fallout 2 for the reasons listed above, the original is still one of the greatest RPGs of all time, and of course, the forerunner for the complete Fallout series, which, for good or bad, is still going strong today. Also, don't give Ian the SMG.R.I.P. Ian, died while rescuing Tandi from the Raiders.R.I.P. Tycho, died while cleansing the Deathclaws from the Warehouse.R.I.P. Dogmeat, died while eradicating the Super Mutants from the Watershed.R.I.P. Katja, died while fighting the Super Mutants in the LA Vault.PS, game can actually run on Windows 7, *cough* Fallout 3 *cough*

Get FAllout FIXT from here: http://www.nma-fallout.com/showthread.php?1945622. Copy that file over into your Fallout folder in Steam, so for example: Program Files (x86)/SteamApps/Common/Fallout3. You're now ready to start Fallout with Steam :3

content:
Posted: September 28, 2012
												I played this game to completion in 2001 when it was only available on cd-rom. Since then I purchased copies on GoG.com and Steam.Fallout is the standard by which every other entry in the franchise should be judged. It is the more focused, balanced, thematically coherent Fallout experience available and the only one released with main designers Tim Cain, Leonard Boyarsky and Jason Anderson still on board.By today's standards the game still hold up well even without fan patches and resolution mods, which are still strongly recommended. The engine and interface does show its age and the sequel, Fallout 2, improves a few things here and there. But the turn-based system and top down camera are not products of their times. First person view and real time combat are not "modern". Changing the former for the latter doesn't constitute an improvement, but a complete change of direction.This kind of game wasn't made that way due to technical limitations. Bethesda released its first Elder Scrolls game in 1994, the year Tim Cain started working on what would become Fallout. No, the intention was to make a computer rpg that felt like playing a pen & paper role playing game. It wasn't about player skills, but player choices. The perspective is from someone playing Dongeons & Dragons, Shadowrun or (more appropriately) GURPS, seeing the world through the maps and descriptions provided by the game master and, ultimately, interpreted by the player's imagination.It isn't the most popular perspective but a legitimate one nonetheless, which suits computer rpgs like a glove. This is how Fallout was meant to be played and, frankly, that's how it should have stayed.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 13, 2014
												Released back in 1997, Fallout is still one of my favourite RPG's ever made. A spiritual successor to Wasteland with heavy influences from the 1981 movie Mad Max, this is a true blue, old school CRPG, no kiddies allowed. Don't expect any level of hand holding here. You're meant to explore, investigate, and actually think about what you do. Dialogue has meaning, and if you say or do the wrong thing, you might just♥♥♥♥♥♥someone off so bad you'll be screwed out of a quest forever. The combat is simple, yet deep enough to be engaging. Battles are turn-based, with action points determining how much you can do each turn. Most of the combat is driven by some heavy dice roll♥♥♥♥♥♥ so expect to be screwed over by a bad critical hit and lose all of your health in a single turn, when previous attack dealt zero damage.Most of the map is empty space. Instead of walking everywhere, you travel on a world map to locations of interest, wherein the real♥♥♥♥♥♥happens. Ranging from small settlements to the ruined remains of ancient cities, these locations are teeming with mysteries to unravel, choices to make, people to meet, items to loot, and a bunch of people to murder, if you're feeling sadistic. Quests often involve multiple outcomes, with several offering the choice between two opposing sides. Whether you're a ruthless mercenary willing to take on any job, a generous saviour, or an evil monster, this game accommodates you, allowing you to approach the game any way you see fit.The game's SPECIAL system offers a surprising amount of depth in character creation. Will you be a gun-toting wanderer who solves problems with his guns, or a smooth-talking snake who solves problems without ever resorting to violence? How about a strongman who smashes his foes with a sledgehammer but is so stupid he can't even carry a conversation with people? Yes, you can do that. No matter which perks you pick or what skills you invest in, you're character will always end up with a different set of strengths and weaknesses. With these systems, the player is given a great deal of options that allow them to fine-tune their character, creating a vastly unique playthrough each time. The story, characters, and setting are all iconic at this point. Though much of its aesthetic is derivative in some way, Fallout carved a unique personality of its own regardless. The narrative is nothing too complicated, and yet it's well-written and impactful at the same time, leading up to one of the best endings in RPG history. There's only three quests in the main plot lines, but these are long involving journeys that will take you all across post-apocalyptic Southern California. As you go from town to town, new quests, jobs, and side activities will open up, which can ultimately serve your primary objectives as well. Know that there is a finite end to the content, however. Though there's a lot to see and do (my first playthrough clocked in at about sixty hours), the game ends once you've beaten the main quest, and outside of that, you can't explore every nook and cranny like you can in Fallout: New Vegas. There's a limit to just how much you can do, but I feel this adds more to the experience, as it lends meaning to your actions. Don't expect to get every skill to a hundred and unlock every perk in a single playthrough.As a game that came out in the late nineties, there are definitely some issues. First, there are major graphical bugs which can be fixed, but may persist nonetheless in more benign forms, which is to be expected of a game that's almost seventeen years old. Then there's some other annoying nitpicks, like unintuitive UI that feels clunky and the odd limitation like not being able to move more than 999 bottle caps at a time when bartering. The AI can be absolute garbage at times, too. Let's put it this way. There were times when I felt grateful that one of my followers was standing in a corner and not fighting, because that means he couldn't shoot me in the back. Without the ability to control your party, things can get pretty frustrating later in the game, when you're rolling with a huge posse to beat the final boss. Hint: save often, and in many slots.So, would I reccomend this game? That depends. Are you looking for an old school CRPG with deep combat and meaningful choices and character growth? If so, then I'll be damned if you can find a better game than Fallout.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												So I recently replayed this game for the first time since the 90's. Here's what I think now, without the nostalgia glasses on.Funny, slow, a bit repetitive but charming story.I probably killed the fun in this game when I figured out an exploit. I like to set my LUCK to 10 at the start of the game so I can more easily get the random event with the UFO. The UFO blast gun is hands down the most powerful gun in this game and it's the only thing you need to be successful. It's lightweight, holds tons of ammo and destroys everything you throw at it. Make sure to dump a ton of points into ENERGY weapons at the start and buy ammo from the hub. Another thing I did that I guess could be considered cheating was I boosted my gambling skill to around 60-70%. I gambled in the hub and the chance of you winning over losing is greater. I took 2 iPhones and postioned them on the keyboard to hold down 1 and 3 on the keyboard I believe. It forces the game to continue gambling rapidly. After 30 minutes I came back to discover I now have 250,000 bottlecaps!Anyways, the point I'm trying to get at is this game is pretty flexible and has some really unique elements you're not going to find anywhere else. I personally prefer this game and FO2 over the new Fallout games. I don't think Bethesda really fully grasped this franchise and how it's supposed to feel. +I'm a big fan of the SPECIAL system.+Combat is a bit lackluster but it works.+Make sure to speed up combat in options, otherwise companions will annoy the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of you.+Dogmeat companion.+The ending boss is hilarious and well worth the journey. Make sure to watch all of his responses on Youtube.-I wasn't a big fan of all they portrayed your vault. I think it would've been better to never have the ability to re-enter the vault 13 so your imagination can go crazy for how it should be in there.

Posted: February 10, 2014
												I have already played this game via buying a soldout software collection. I spent many hours playing this game and I admit I needed a walkthrough as the difficulty of this game is based on you have a limited number of days, based on the storyline.The Story: For those who don't know, you start out as a vault dweller whose parents took shelter in vault 13 along with many others to avoid the coming nucular missiles at the height of World War 3. The residents are meant to stay in the vault until such a time as the raditation levels have gone down low enough as to not be a issue, however your vault's water chip has broken. The main source of drinking water based on a recycling system in the vault. As they have no other option, they need to send out one of the residents and you volunteer to enter a world that has completely changed since your ancestors walked the surface during the war and find a new water chip as the Overseer knows of a nearby vault (Vault 15) which may have a spare chip to use.The combat system is turn-based and on a invisible hex-grid. It is also based on Action Points and in combat uses what was called the VATS system where you can aim for a specific point on the creature, but if you were to take the trait that lets you shoot more often (forgot it's name) you will be unable to do accurate aiming. It's a old-school PC RPG where your decisions are totally up to you and ethics are optional in how you get the waterchip or where from. With multiple endings and detailed tellings of what happened to the places you visited, after you left leaves the game open for many multiple play throughts  for endless gameplay and always discover new things and easter eggs such as "the holy hand grenade." and other references too numerous to count.A brilliant game and well worth a purchas if you are after a old-school RPG, but as it is so old and not altered for modern systems (unlike on GoG) you will need to look up how to run the game without weird graphical glitches.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												The Fallout series has been known for it's great exploration, looting fun, and character progression as you endure many different radioactive wastelands. But I think that Fallout 1 is by far the most immersive of them all. Although it's late 90's graphics are nothing compared to the modern graphic card melting games, this game's experience is told through reading, dialogue, scrounging for information, and plain old exploration. This game gives a more vivid and detailed image of what the reality of a open wasteland filled with murder and death feels lke than any other fallout's even come close to. That's more than enough reason to pick this game up, especially now that you can play it without uninstalling windows, thanks to Bethesda's new hi-resolution update!

Posted: March 25
												My introduction to the Fallout series was Fallout 3. I had never heard of the series before that, but after a few months (because I wasn't paying much attention to the community) I heard long time fans of the series were upset with how Bethesda handled the game. I wasn't completely disillusioned with Bethesda yet at this time and I hadn't started looking at things more critically, so I didn't understand the problem back then. I also had nothing else to compare it to at the time.Then Fallout: New Vegas came and it was better than FO3 in every way. Then Fallout 4 came and it was worse than about anything I could compare it to in very nearly every way. During this time I had tried to get into Fallout 1 a number of times, but never really did, farthest I had made it was to Shady Sands before quitting. Until this past week, that is. According to Steam I've played about 18 hours in the past week and I'm really loving it so far and I can see why so many long time fans have an issue with Fallout 3 and 4.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												Wow, where do I begin? You can probably tell by looking at my profile picture that I'm a fan of this particular franchise. Let me tell you a story about how my Fallout journey began... Back when I was a young lad, I was thumbing through a gaming mag (believe it or not, that's what we had to do before the internet exploded) and saw a page dedicated to Fallout 2, with some screenshots and synopsis, etc. 'This is interesting' I thought to myself, fresh off the high that I got from playing Metal Gear Solid and Final Fantasy VII; I was excited for more deep, mature and thought-provoking games. But then I noticed that it was a computer game, which is, sadly, rather hard to play when you don't have a computer. So I let it go. Fast forward a year or two later and there's a new PC in the den, but by then I had already forgotten about that obscure magazine article... But luckily, later that year on my 17th birthday, I was in a retail store looking for ways to waste my money. While walking toward the Playstation aisle I passed by a small section dedicated to PC games. It was a pathetic display, mostly consisting of FMV puzzle games and flight sims. But then I saw it... like a black hole pulsing with darkness and malice... Fallout 1 and 2, together, for a mere $10. I looked over my shoulder to verify that no one was watching as I picked up the M-rated game(s), one of the few I placed my hands on. There was a stigma attatched to M-rated games, back before they were making billions, and they were few and far between. The mere sight of the M was enough to make parents cringe. Thanks to Mortal Kombat and Doom, there was the notion that these games were evil and soul-stealing. So as I gazed with awe at the box art, I was thankful that my brother had driven me to the store and not my mother. I took it to the counter, and for the first and last time ever, I was asked to show my ID for the purchase. I was nervous, but I was 17, so there was nothing they could do to stop me.I waited until my parents had gone to bed before installing the game. I had an idea of what to expect, but I admit I was still trying to wrap my head around the concept of a world where the Jestons-inspired retro version of the future was true, and the cold war turned into a nuclear reality. I had never heard of such nonsense in my life, but somehow, it made perfect sense. 'War never changes'... the haunting opening entered into my mind and settled comfortably, as if my mind had already decided that this was going to be something special. And Oh, how it was, and is... Fallout is brilliant. A dark, atmospheric, violent and oddly loveable adventure into a post-apocalyptic wasteland. Taking inspiration from the Road Warrior and twisting it into something grand and absurd. I won't go into anything specific about the story and setting, because by this point, 15 years later, you may already know enough. If not, you are in for a treat. I would say that it still holds up, but that's because I got in when it was still pretty new, so my perspective is a bit skewed. What I will say is that still, to this day, even with all the amazing advancements in games, it has some things about it that have yet to be surpassed. The exceptionally well-concieved levelling system, for example, is probably the best there has ever been in a game of any kind.   I could spend another hour writing about why I love this game so much, but if you are one of those people that have yet to experience it, I think it best you go in with as little information as possible. I can not recommend this game enough; It is truly a masterpiece that every RPG fan should know by heart.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												It's Worth It, Just Be Prepared to Mod ItFallout's strengths lie in two areas: atmosphere and customization. The atmosphere of Fallout is amazing. It's one of the few games I feel that has gotten its atmosphere down right, combining a dangerous and barren post-apocalyptia with a retro 1950s undertone, and maintains a great balance between feeling ridiculous and serious. The story isn't anything to write home about, but it's an effective motivating force for the game. With that in mind, know that if you pick up Fallout, do NOT consult any walkthrough or wiki when playing it because, trust me, it'll spoil the fun. Fallout is the type of RPG that's made a whole lot better when you live with your consequences and aren't certain about where the story will take you. As for the customization, Fallout has it in plentiful supply and I'm not just refering to the moral choices available to you. Rather, it's the character customization which is some of the best. Between getting to specialize in a wide variety of weapon types to being able to having your intelligence level effect your choices in the game (Anything below an Intelligence of 4 makes you a bumbling idiot, and this is reflected in game by your dialogue options which are limited to "me have trouble thinking") there's a great amount of replayability to this game. However, while I recommend Fallout it does come with a bundle of bugs, some of which have the potential to be game breaking such as being trapped in a corner by an unmovable companion NPC. Because of this, I recommend you mod it. My personal recommendation is called "Fallout FIXT" by Sduibek. It's a great megamod which fixes a lot of problems, and is VERY customizable allowing you to choose between general bug fixes and improvements, or changing the feel of the game entirely. It's a great download. Anyway, Fallout is a fantastic (though not a perfect) game. I highly recommend it, ESPECIALLY if you can bag it for cheap!

content:
Posted: July 11, 2016
												The game hasn't aged well, but I could see it being big back when it was released. This is the game that started it all before Bethedsa took over the series and made Fallout 3. The gameplay mechanics thus are vastly different from the more recent titles. For one thing, you play in a top down perspective and basically attack enemies during turn based combat. However, you can move your character around freely during your turn so it's not as restricted as other turn based games. You also have various RPG elements such as stats you can improve, loot and inventory, and different outcomes based on your dialogue choices. I like the amount of freedom the game gives you since you can pretty much play the game how you want. There's a good amount of side quests that you can do if you want and the lore is there if you're interested in that stuff. What I don't like about the game is two things: the interface and the combat speed. The interface can take some getting used to because moving your character around, accessing weapons/inventory, etc. is done in an unconventional manner in my opinion. Also, the combat in this game can take forever especially if you are facing multiple enemies. This is because the characters move so slow when they walk and going through all the animations can end up making a large battle take 15-30 minutes. I wouldn't recommend this game to people who haven't played old 90s PC games before because like I said the interface and the combat mechanics can ruin the experience for you. However if you want the full Fallout experience this is where it all started.

content:
Posted: December 16, 2015
												For those of you who got this game after playing 3, New Vegas and/or 4, prepare for a whole different cup of tea.This game is a isometric top down RPG(in case you didnt see the screenshots) and is a game that does not hold your hand whatsoever.And this being an older Fallout game means.....1) No tutorials and you are just thrown into the game straight.2) No quest markers meaning you might bang your head trying to find the correct location.3) You have to figure things out on your own.4) You have to save frequently lest you lose progress.5) Combat is significantly different that what you are used in future Fallouts, being slow and tactical.6) Inventory management and bartering is more cumbersome.7) Movement and exploration is slow with random encounters of random difficulty.If any of those turn you off then I suggest you rethink your purchase. Other than that, the game has a compelling story, great characters and quests to take on, its pretty much what you expect from the Fallout games, you are tasked with a huge responsibility and you set out to explore the wasteland. Its a very good game for its time and if you can get over the old game tropes I listed above, you are gonna have a good time.And look.....just be safe out there...ok.

content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
												Personal rating: 10/10Replayability: HighBudget: Worth it if you're a fan only as the game is very old and dated. If you have no knowledge of the game, don't bother throwing a cent at it. Lenght: Unknown. At least a week. Probably more. Fallout is an old classic. If you've played fallout 3 or New Vegas and taken an interest in the series and want to try this, I seriously recommend watching a few youtube vids first, as the game is very old. It's not exactly easy to adjust to a game this dated. That said, even on windows 7, it plays without error. The game will probably remind a lot of people, initially of the more recent fallout games. They seem do have done a great job of passing on the setting. Bear in mind that this is turn-based combat, and top-down view and isometric. It's truly an oldie. The game is crafted with a lot of detail in mind. Each map allows for every single item to be examined, and unlike in more recent RPG's in general, you will not be told when to use skills. There is no tutorial (to my knowledge) but the game isn't super hard to figure out, and if it becomes tricky there are guides on the internet. It's a good holiday project, but hardly a treat for a gamer who seeks a visual challenge and revolutionary gameplay. For gamers interested in gaming history or people in general who can stand playing old games, you will have a chance to experience a rolepalying game that dates to the time when people really knew how to craft a world with eye for detail. Personally I tried fallout when I was a child, having barely a clue what I was doing. I've since stumbled on it again and again with friends who time and time again referred to it as a classic. It truly is.

content:
Posted: February 4, 2015
												Having been a veteran of Fallout near 13 years now, I recall my first time playing the first Fallout. Back then I was pretty young and didn't have exactly a firm grasp of reality and the seriousness of Fallout.Now, upon purchasing the classic pack, I delved back into the world of Fallout, and after having some memories flood back and some trials and errors, I once again (without help this time) beat Fallout, I survived, I learned, I made decisions that made me question my humanity as a whole, thank god for the comic relief in game otherwise I would've gotten depressed real fast! Now that the compliments are outta the way, let me begin by saying this a game befitting anyone's game library.Fallout, as a whole, makes you question and discover yourself (Get ready for group therapy session!), its amazing locales and set-up make it a unique game to play, I could actually spend hours trying to figure out what and where I find the Red Ryder LE BB Gun (Special Encounter). Beautifully detailed yet desolate and unforgiving landscapes and settlements make for a great experience, mechanics are smooth and simple, once you figure them out of course.I was pretty much thrown into the game without prior knowledge of the controls or how combat and interaction function, once I remembered some bits and pieces and tried different things, it was simple.A colorful cast of characters that antagonizes and emphasises on a great deal of comical and serious matters, each one, be it a "talking head" or just a regular NPC, will have you wonder "Do I join this group? Do I shoot this guy? Why does the man keep screaming about cheese? Should I prevent or stay out of this fight that possibly decides the outcome of an entire game?"Ladies and gentlemen, I tried my best to explain what Fallout entails, what it does, how it makes me feel, and how much I love it. But I sadly cannot put into full detail how amazing Fallout is.All I can say is Fallout is like a wonderful sight of a game, a whole lot of what-ifs, and lovely interaction.Though humanity may have blown itself up, that is not the end of the story, because war... War never changes...10/10.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2016
												EDITED (rewritten) : the negative mark is explained below*, but the game is original, good and fun in terms of RPG adventure and freedom of movement.WARNING : once you are aware that the saved games tend to break, you can avoid much frustration.  How: save your current game in many slots and never save in Combat mode (even if there is no actual combat, do not save in that stance or mode).On a technical level, the game is a bit painful, but you can greatly make it more player-friendly and more fun with the version called "Fallout Fixt" : independant programmers and modders have combined to allow a much better experience (source: nma-fallout.com ).  For example, the 'Fixt' version allows to control the companions directly (!), pressing ESC closes most windows, etc. * When you sell a game on Steam for 10 $, without giving a warning about a game breaking bug (that can be circumvented), it is not ethical nor honorable.  I am told that the original company no longer exist, but someone is making money now.  Everything can be justified with logic or reason, but I don't accept that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.  The game has been improved many times back then, but the game breaking save bug remains (i.e. they could just block the possibility of saving in combat mode for example).  The game is worth it once you know that.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2014
												+ amazingly interesting quests+ great RPG system, perks+ unforgettable soundtrack+ dark, yet humorous+ funny and believable dialogues+ incredible atmosphere+ challenging to beat; not overly hard though+ runs perfecty on modern systems after one fan-made patch- doesn't run perfectly on modern systems without the fan-made patchThe ultimate post-nuclear experience. Forget the F3/NV; Fallout 1 (and Fallout 2) is how the post-apocalyptic world could actually look like.Harshness, seriousness and darkness of the post-apocalyptic world? It's in it.Humour, hyperbole, light tone and pop-culture references? It's in there, without diminishing the serious tone of the game.INCREDIBLE dialogues and your possibilities in it. Great music, fits the atmosphere perfectly. Decent storyline. The number of possibilities on how you could play through this game is uncountable. You can beat this game in 9 minutes 17 seconds (literally, speedrun is on youtube somewhere) or in average 20 hours without getting bored for 1 second. For me it's possibly the best RPG out there.New Fallouts were decent games but sh*t-tier Fallouts. You want to know why is Fallout considered one of the best RPG series ever? Play this (or Fallout 2) and forget the sequels for now.↑ all of this applies to Fallout 2 as well

content:
Posted: August 6, 2012
												For all its weeping sores, the best PC game of the 1990s except for Homeworld, and probably the best RPG on Steam. Lots of freedom, likeable characters, an intriguing backstory, a main quest you can straight-up fail, some of the greatest endings in any game, and a gorgeous dark-ambient soundtrack.On the down side, the interface is clunky and slow, especially inventory. NPC sidekicks can be frustrating to work with and will often harm you or each other. (It's not nearly as bad as some clumsy players will tell you it is.) And a few quests can hinge on pixel hunting - not intentionally, but simply because items can be hard to spot against the dithery backgrounds.Be advised that all combat in this game is turn-based. It's fun, but it's NOT optional like you see in Fallout 3 and New Vegas. You will take turns spending action points on a hex grid, every fight. Fallout is a slow RPG. It is not by any definition an action game.Highest possible recommendation.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												Although somewhat different from FO3, and FNV, Fallout is definitely a classic. The range of weapons is quite large and fun to try out. Essentially, the arsenal available in Fallout ranges from melee weapons like knives, combat knives, crowbars, batons, sledgehammers, brass knuckles, the power fist, the ripper to singlehanded firearms like the laser pistol, the alien blaster, 10mm pistol, the 14mm pistol, the desert eagle, the .223 pistol, 10mm smg to two handed firearms like the hunting rifle, the sniper rifle, the combat shotgun, the shotgun, the minigun, the flamer, the rocket launcher, the plasma rifle, the gatling laser etc. The combat system is essentially turn based. When combat is initiated by the player or by enemies, the player must spend action points to access their inventory, fire a weapon, reload a weapon, or when picking something up. Essentially, action points are based on the players starting agility level. So, if the player modifies a preset character to have an agility of 5, their action points will be 7. According to the Fallout Wiki it's based on equation like so "Agility level + agility level/2=action points." To improve your agility level you can choose the Action boy Perk when leveling up. When actually hitting the target you may find yourself chuckling in amusement at the explosion of fallen enemies from the impact of a laser beam from your newly acquired laser rifle or being able to watch the falling burnt corpses of your enemies after engaging them with a flamethrower. My only grimace is the combat system itself where players even with a 95% chance to hit a target can often time miss. Despite that, the combat itself is much more enjoyable later in the game with end game weapons and higher combat skill levels. The story line is short. SPOILER. There isn't much aside from a few hours of gameplay for the main story. The main story essentially is about attaining a water chip to save your home, Vault 13. While it may take new players hours to find the water chip veteran players may be able to accomplish this task in less than an hour. Just a tip, but if you can't find the water chip in the allotted time of 120 or so in game days, you can visit the water merchants at the Hub and pay them 2000 bottle caps to get an additional 100 days. Note: after a certain amount of days the environment in the game changes as the super mutants over run Necropolis (the place where you get the water chip). This essentially makes your task much harder b/c if you do not have better quality weapons like rifles, combat shotguns, grenades, flamethrowers, etc. you may not be able to kill them as easily. After acquiring the water chip, the main story develops a bit more as the overseer (leader) of your vault tasks you with destroying and discovering the secret behind the super mutants at the once abondoned secret U.S. military base. Within this story, the player has a few choices as they can decide how the fate of the wasteland turns out. Aside from that, there are a handful of side quests that can be found in the game. You can even join the Brotherhood of steel, the thieves guild, kill the Gun Runners, kill the Khans, etc.A very basic and nice feature is the ability to get companions! Their features are very basic b/c it can seems like you can not equip them with more advanced gear like power armour, or trade back gear if youu decide to use them as a pack mules unlesss you use the barter system. From my understanding there are only three followers you can attain. You can recruit Ian from Shady Sands for 100 bottle caps, Katja from the Boneyard library for free, and dogmeat, a dog located in Junktown. For the most part, these followers can be useful in absorbing the brunt of damage from early game enemies, but are easily killed later on by super mutants and the like who are often equipped with gatling guns, laser rifles, flamethrowers, etc. For the most part, new players can expect at least 10-20 hours through the main story and side quests. P.S. make sure to make additional saves. There is no autosave feature in this game. If you screw up somewhere in your game you can always revert back to an earlier save. Also, some skills are worthless like the Outdoorsman skill and traps.
