content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
FalloutIf you're a fan of the series and you haven't played the original Fallout yet, I highly recommened it.The gameplay and graphics are obviously very different from the more modern Fallout 3 and New Vegas, but the RPG and exploration elements are all there. Unlike those, the original Fallout is an isometric (not exactly, but whatever) and turn based RPG.The main theme, concept and overall design are also shared with the other Fallout games.You can still interact with every NPC, either by talking to them, bartering, stealing from them or just slaughtering them however you please. Watch out though, you'll easily die if you go up against enemies much better equipped than you or if you're significantly outnumbered. You can also explore and interact with objects such as lockers, dresses, desks, etc... and search for various loot.Most (if not all) of the chems like Stimpaks and Psychos are here too, along with weapons from pistols and rifles, to miniguns and energy weapons. The armor is slightly different, but you have Mad Max's leather jacket and Power Armor, so nothing to complain about there.You have companions that will follow you around and help in combat, like good ol' Dogmeat.The way you navigate around the map is a bit different though. The wasteland isn't just one huge map. If you want to travel to other cities/areas (there's 13 different locations, if I'm not mistaken) you leave the one you're at and a map comes up. From there, you choose where to go and all you do is watch a cute little map marker (you) move towards the destination, unless you encounter something (like raiders, mutants, a corpse to loot, etc..) or you deliberately stop.The leveling system is pretty much the same, where you allocate SPECIAL points and choose 2 perks at the begining  of the game and gain experience to level up. You can then level up your skills (which I also think are the same from Fallout 3 & NV) and earn a perk every few levels.One thing that's noticeably different however, is the way you make use of your skills. If you want to, for example, pick a lock, you'll have to go your Skilldex and select the skill you want to use (in this case, the Lockpick skill) and then you click on the object you want to use the skill on (the lock). Other skills also work like this, where you select the skill then the target to use the skill on. Except for Sneak, which you just click to start sneaking and that's it.So yeah, to sum it up, if you're a Fallout fan you should definitely check this one out, even if just for the lore.If you're new to the series, you're better off picking up 3 or NV first.Side-note: This comes from a teenager who played Fallout 3 and New Vegas before this one, so there's no nostalgia involved here.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												Don't kid yourself, this game is OLD, almost ancient.You should probably only play this if you are a die hard Fallout fan or you're really into post apocalyptic isometric RPGs.You start off with almost no weapons from your Vault. Your mission: Find water. You only have a certain amount of "days" to do that (in game the time does not stand still). I don't know what happens if you fail, to be honest.You will have no one holding your hand in this game. No one. You have no quest log (as far as I can tell), you only find out what to do and where to go by talking to people (no, they do not have exclamation marks for quests). They give you missions, directions, intel, etc. These missions will have consequences. If you simply murder stuff or do shady deals and people find out, you get negative karma points and some people will be hostile. That being said, the choices you can make are rather nice, but can also screw you over. There are good walkthroughs out there if you want the optimal way to play, i.e. where to go, who to talk to and how to get the most XP and bottle caps.The latter are the game's currency. Although you do not strictly need them, because everything can be bought with everything. All items in the game have a certain value and you can simply trade them in. However, items also have a weight associated to them, so the bottle caps are definitely worth having. You can, of course, only carry so much (depends on your strength value). However, there is a trick, whereby your companion, which you can hire or not, can seemingly carry an unlimited amount of items. Of course he won't give them back to you for free, but you can steal it from them and they won't complain apparently.Your starting values and skills will be important and you can already mess up the game here. Every now and then you get a level up and can choose a new perk or upgrade one (not every levelup). You can also invest skill points into your various skills, from picking locks, to sneaking, conversation, healing or different combat traits. You can level a skill up to 100%. I would strongly suggest to invest into small arms initially, as most weapons, especially early on are in that category (from pistols to shotguns to rifles). And missing in this game can be your death.Combat is done turn based with action points and initiative. The values are often hard to gauge though. In any case you will usually have some sort of firearm and armor equipped. You can swap weapons mid combat, but it costs action points (AP). Everything costs AP. You can either fire your weapon unaimed, which costs less AP, or aimed. The latter allows you to target specific parts of your opponent. For example shooting and wounding the leg causes monsters to be slower (i.e. lose AP). Shooting the arms may cause opponents to miss more. Shooting the eyes give you a chance of blinding them. And a headshot can potentially do the most damage. Of course your hit percentage depends on your skill with a weapon type and the distance to the target. Funnily enough you can also fire your sniper rifle from point blank range. Generally speaking, the more damage a weapon does, the more AP it requires. You will also have to reload at times, which also costs AP and potentially your whole move. Some weapons also offer other modes of fire. Automatic weapons have a burst fire mode, which costs lots of AP and wastes lots of ammo and should only be used on close targets, but can kill targets quickly and also hurt other enemies nearby. Speaking of ammo. Every weapon in the game uses a different type of ammo, so try to specialise on 1 or 2 weapons, otherwise you will just be carrying around lots of additional ammo, which takes up weight.If you want to and find one you can also hire a companion...you should ♥♥♥♥ing do that. I can't imagine how to win the game without one. Tycho for example has loads of HPs and can fire almost any weapon. Be aware though that there is friendly fire in the game and the friendly AI cannot be controlled or given any orders. They will act on their own and they're ♥♥♥♥ing stupid, so don't stand in the way and try to keep them alive. It doens't help that you can't see their HPs...you can give the AI weapons and they will use whatever they deem best from their inventory.Movement and menus are a pain for modern days to be honest. Combat is "ok", but it just has this "feel" to it that makes it great somehow.Overall I like the game, though the story in general isn't very good imho. It's the individual people and missions that make this one entertaining.There is no difficulty setting I think, so I would urge you to read some guides on what to do and how to even play the game, because there is no tutorial.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												Don't kid yourself, this game is OLD, almost ancient.You should probably only play this if you are a die hard Fallout fan or you're really into post apocalyptic isometric RPGs.You start off with almost no weapons from your Vault. Your mission: Find water. You only have a certain amount of "days" to do that (in game the time does not stand still). I don't know what happens if you fail, to be honest.You will have no one holding your hand in this game. No one. You have no quest log (as far as I can tell), you only find out what to do and where to go by talking to people (no, they do not have exclamation marks for quests). They give you missions, directions, intel, etc. These missions will have consequences. If you simply murder stuff or do shady deals and people find out, you get negative karma points and some people will be hostile. That being said, the choices you can make are rather nice, but can also screw you over. There are good walkthroughs out there if you want the optimal way to play, i.e. where to go, who to talk to and how to get the most XP and bottle caps.The latter are the game's currency. Although you do not strictly need them, because everything can be bought with everything. All items in the game have a certain value and you can simply trade them in. However, items also have a weight associated to them, so the bottle caps are definitely worth having. You can, of course, only carry so much (depends on your strength value). However, there is a trick, whereby your companion, which you can hire or not, can seemingly carry an unlimited amount of items. Of course he won't give them back to you for free, but you can steal it from them and they won't complain apparently.Your starting values and skills will be important and you can already mess up the game here. content:
Posted: October 30, 2015
												=--------REVIEW SYNOPSIS-------------=Ah... the classic. It's ancient... very old. Despite that however, Bethesda still shows love to this timeless classic created by Fallout's original makers; Interplay. This is the one that started them all. It hasn't aged well as far as graphics and gameplay goes, but it's true to the RPG format, and one of the original US Turn-based RPGs from the 90s era. It spans the entireity of the Mojave Dersert-region... more precisely, the deserts of the California and Nevada regions. You begin as a Lone Wanderer set upon a quest to restore your Vault-Tek™ Vault's water chip; the sole thing that purifies the disease-ridden, irradiated waters of the surface world so that your vault's inhabitants will have fresh water to drink. It having broken down, you're sent out to find a new one. Along the way, you'll encounter many strange people... and many deadly enemies, not-so interesting companions... but companions none-the-less.=--------PROGRESSIVE POINTS----------=*Elder to the first US-based RPGs*Turn-based (You are free to plan your next move, it could be your last!)*Compatability/Optimized for Windows 7+ Operating Systems*Compatability/Still contains the original version for 98/XP-based Operating Systems*Brutal difficulty (Just how you remember it)=--------CONTRARY POINTS-------------=*Ancient graphical detail*Linear storyline*Limited range of weaponry/gear*Brutal difficulty (No forgiveness for mistakes)*Clunky UI (For what it was back in the day, hasn't aged well IMHO)=--------PERSONAL GAME RESULTS-------=I give this game a 8/10I give this game a [LEGENDARY™ MOLE RAT STEW]

content:
Posted: May 19, 2013
												A very immsersive experience from back in the day, Fallout is everything  a role-playing game should be. You've got tons of options in how to customize your character, and can do practically anything. Someone insult you? Give em a bullet to the brain, a verbal smackdown, or a grenade in their pants! The plot is also well told, though requires some exploring to truly understand.All of this, however, is overshadowed by one unfortunate flaw: current computers cannot properly handle it. This leads to many graphical bugs that make it nearly impossible to play. Thankfully, many people on the internet and even here on Steam have come up with solutions. Look around for a mod called Fallout FIXT on the site No Mutants Allowed, and don't  afraid to ask for help!

content:
Posted: September 12, 2015
												Although this game is extremely boring for me, I can see its appeal. Being introduced to video games in the 3D era, I am somewhat allegric to old games (2006 onward is okay for me). I understand that most of the mechanics in this game are very outdated, because most of the mechanics in this game have been refined and improved in modern games. Therefore, there is a lack of something new or something that is very attention-grabbing. Most of the NPC's don't have their own audio dialogue and character models, the UI is very clunky resulting in repetative gameplay, and the start of the game is very boring and un-fun. I have played through an hour (or more) of this game and I haven't actually been introduced to new quests besides the main quest. Quests aren't very organized and the game does not hold your hand in trying to find where you are actually supposed to go (there are no quest markers, from what I've seen). If you've seen gameplay of this game, you might be fooled into thinking it's sort of an open world game. Actually, the world is separated into grids and you have to travel via map or cross the border to get to the next one. Combat is also very dull and repetative. I have to stab a mole rat 4 times before it gets to die (sometimes I even miss), and guns aren't very useful for me because I miss anyway. The VATS system isn't very useful, because it takes a few clicks to actually GET to the menu, and all that is probably not worth it because you're not even sure if you are even going to HIT that body part. Combat is also very slow. It takes a few clicks to actually shoot/stab someone. It also takes a few clicks to interact with objects and the enviroment as well. The first time I finally got to talk to someone, I had a lot of things to say, but most of those choices were pointless and the responses were boring anyway. In conclusion, I can understand why so many people like this game. Its charm is wonderful and the character creation is one of its strongest features, which the game supports very well. Too bad Fallout's other mechanics didn't hold up as much as its character creation did. Just like borderlands, I wish this game's world could have been introduced into a different genre, and that's what Fallout 3 did. Thank god for Todd Howard, eh? I would only recommend buying this game if it's very cheap or if you think you could tollerate its outdated mechanics and repetative gameplay. If not, this isn't the game for you and I would definately recommend buying Fallout 3, which aged very well. Out of all the games that I sincerely wish could have been remade into the modern era, Fallout would be one of them...EDIT: After forcing myself to play this game, after about 3 hours I got hooked and I played the heck out of it. I really, really like it!!! Although it says that I played only 4 hours, I probably played almost 40 because I have the Fallout Fixt mod and steam doesn't detect when it's being used. I strongly recommend playing this with a walkthrough the first time around, and then play it again without. But, to be honest, I don't want to play this game again... instead, I'll play Fallout 2!!! Fallout 2, watch out, 'cause here I come!

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												This game is the beginning of my favourite series of games ever. I assumed that due to it's age and the companies behind it, that it would be pretty bad and boring, but I was very wrong. This game is full of a fair amount of quests that all have good story to them. The visuals are fine when the HD patch is applied. There is lack of audio in the game aside from the odd sound effect and combat related sounds such as gunshot. The game also has fairly slow paced gameplay and you'd have to be patient to deal with it at times. The game has turn-based combat using a targeting system called "V.A.T.S." that works on percentages. The games RPG elements are detailed with many perks and skills to train as well as using speech options that effect how the game plays out.If you're a fan of post-apocalyptic setting, don't mind the dated graphics and slow paced gameplay. This game is for you.12/15 - "Brilliant beginning to a brilliant series"

												Things I Liked:Good StoryVery Strategy-Centric - hexagonal tiles mean that strategy is keyVariety in weaponsLore is really interestingThings I Didn't:More RTS-like than RPG, although RPG elements are thereThe graphics do not work on modern machines - many graphical glitches on my machineCombat is action point reliant - can be pretty dullGame mechanics are not very well explained - trial and errorOnce you die, you lose your character (may be a welcome challenge for some, but I am not a fan)No autosaves (adds to annoyance of above point)The Fallout series is well known by the gaming community, mainly for Fallout 3 and New Vegas but many have missed the first entry in the series, which can be picked up pretty cheaply on Steam.I had pretty low expectations for this game, being released in 1997 and all, but even so I was honestly disappointed from the get go, when I couldn't boot up the game, and when I did the opening cutscene wouldn't show without rainbows fizzing across my screen.Anyway, as I got into the game these glitches went away for the most part, and I could get onto playing the game, which was difficult without any clues on where to go or how quickly (you are given a time limit to complete the game, by the way). The storyline you follow is dull, although the background information is really interesting, with the end-of-the-world scenario that kicked it all off in pretty much every game since. be prepared though, this information is pretty much shoved in your face every time you talk to anyone. They respond to a two word question with a five hundered word essay, and you have to read it all to make sense of what's going on.The combat is what I thought the Fallout series would excel at, but I was wrong. enemies surround you far too quickly, you have to use 'action points' like a turn based strategy, in fact that's what the combat is, and I find it a hard concept to master.Overall this game is great for its story and lore but not so strong with its combat and mechanics in the modern era. Recommended if you can put up with the flaws of older titles.

content:
Posted: May 18, 2016
												The controls aren't initially too bad, especially when you finally master them. Unfortunately, Black Isle Studios didn't have the knack to implement an abundance of voice actors. Truth be told there are only a handful of them in the entire game. Everything else is good old fashion dialogue. Sure, you might here me and other people complain about this. But let's just say, for the shake of this review. I get over the fact the game only has a limited amount of voice actors until Fallout 3. The only major problem I've encountered thus far with Fallout 1 through 2 (including Fallout Tactics) is the despicable combat system. I mean this combat system sucks.. I'm talking atari style combat.. A friendly individual fires first, then a hostile target fires second. It essentially goes back and fourth until one or the other is dead. This is extremely unrealistic, and truthfully. I don't believe there was any excuse for this whatsoever. Take my word for it, I'm a huge fan of the Fallout series; but this is just ridiculous. In closing this message, I want to add the story is of course outstanding. I hope one day they'll consider doing a remastered version of both Fallout 1 and Fallout 2. Preferably with Fallout 4's new creation engine.

												This fantastic RPG has been in my Steam Library for some time now, and have posessed the desire to dive into it for quite a while. I suppose it is feels just that fantastic to obliterate a base full of supermutants with a 40 shot burst minigun. For those who do not enjoy the turn-based style game, this is still highly recommended. It is a different style of combat compared to the modern first person Fallout titles, however it feels just as awesome and immersive to roam the wastelands and destroy the enemy. 10/10 Great GameP.S. Give the controls some time, you will come to understand and enjoy them.

												Thumbs Up!  Best Fallout Ever!  Look at those graphics.  OMGosh!  So Cool!;POk, really!  Why would anyone recommend this?  Well, for a blast from the past.  No mods!  No High Def!  Oh and some pretty tough game play (at least for me).  I picked it up simply for storyline and slight nostalgia.  Which is what I think most players picked it up for.  To complete the set and get that little bit of Lore you always wondered about.  Seriously, buy this game only if you want to experience the classics.  It's like buying Final Fantasy 1 cause you enjoyed 10 so much that you want to know the first game better.  It's a completely different beast but worth experiencing even if you never finish it. Or like playing Pac Man or Pong.  It's a classic worth trying.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												This game is the beginning of my favourite series of games ever. I assumed that due to it's age and the companies behind it, that it would be pretty bad and boring, but I was very wrong. This game is full of a fair amount of quests that all have good story to them. The visuals are fine when the HD patch is applied. There is lack of audio in the game aside from the odd sound effect and combat related sounds such as gunshot. The game also has fairly slow paced gameplay and you'd have to be patient to deal with it at times. The game has turn-based combat using a targeting system called "V.A.T.S." that works on percentages. The games RPG elements are detailed with many perks and skills to train as well as using speech options that effect how the game plays out.If you're a fan of post-apocalyptic setting, don't mind the dated graphics and slow paced gameplay. This game is for you.12/15 - "Brilliant beginning to a brilliant series"

content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												This isn't a game, this Is an Experience. :DDon't buy it if you don't like reading, roleplay, using your brain, a challenge, or strategy. The combat really makes you think as opposed to just shooting randomly in big 3D open worlds where everything is a movie and holds your hand. There's no Autosave, sunshine. Welcome to the 90's. If you forget to hit that save button after defeating a horde of deathclaws and get shot a screen over by a bandit, tough Sh*t. Do it again.You'll learn to appreciate gameplay over graphics for once in your close minded life.Unlike the failure Fallout 4, (A blasphemy to the genre and series) there is more to the combat than just meets the eye.Chances are, if you're not a fan of dungeon crawlers, and whine about Nethack and the like as being "too hard" (Wah Wah you little baby) then go lower your IQ some more and buy the modern garbage they call video games and stop wasting your time on this classic.This game will wreck you, make you cry and then hug you and give you a cookie. It's not for the faint of heart, and neither is Real life when you think about it.If you think this review is too brutal, that's because this game twice as brutal.Fallout can change a man (but war, war never changes), I used to be as soft as a kitten before playing this harcore Sh*t. "Git Gud or Git Gud Not, there is no try."And you're gonna need to memorize these keyboard functions before you play, otherwise, expect carpal tunnel from all the clickin. So Get that pen and paper ready, grasshopper.:A - AttackC- Character screeI - InventoryP- pipboyZ - Pipboy clockHome- Center on PlayerS - Skilldex1 - Sneak2- Lockpick3- Steal4- Traps5- First Aid6- Doctor7- Science8- RepairB- Toggle active itemsN- Toggle item mode> - Rotate left< - Rotate rightF6- QuicksaveTAB- AutomapShift + Click - Run to designated location (Extremely helpful, no longer will my carpal tunnel act up from all the double clicks.)Enter - Ends Combat mode (if no enemies nearby)SPACE - Ends Combat turn

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												Fallout is a controversial came to me because there are many good and bad things about it. It can be genuinely fun, but you have to be willing to overlook a few problems. For one, non-violent character builds (i.e. focus on skills like sneak, speech, science, etc) are pretty much impossible to play for several reasons. A) There are random encounters in this game, which you will get constantly while fast traeveling. Unless you're really, really, lucky, you will get murdered by raiders and scorpions over and over again. B) You will miss out on XP through combat, which will make you way too low level. Secondly, most skills in this game are uneccessary or plainly useless. In order to have fun, I recomend you play the following character. Choose gifted and fast shot as traits, lockpick, science, and small guns as tag skills. Then go with 2 cha, 4 int, 4 str, 10 end, 10 agility, 10 per, and 5 luck. Trust me, just do it.It kind of feels like a let down in that you don't get a lot of freedom to do what you want. This game is very combat-oriented.  Another problem is the graphics. It personally didn't bother me, but I know it can upset some people. If that's important to you, maybe don't play it. Lastly, the game is arbitrarily hard. The first time I saw a mutant, I got blasted to bits in one hit. Make  sure to save often and I recomend playing on easy, because Fallout enemies are super unfair. However, don't let that stop you from enjoying it. There are many good things about it also. What I really enjoyed was the simple fact that no other franchise really makes post-apocalytpic RPGs. The enemies look all mad max style, how cool is that? The setting is really cool, and frankly, underused. I've always maintained that interesting settings *make* RPGs. The story of Fallout is actually pretty interesting, even if it is rather bare-bones. I was also really impressed by the goal of Fallout: you have only 150 days to get a water chip, which your vault needs. You're on your own and you have to figure out where it is quickly. It's almost like a sleuth or detective RPG. If you feel like the good outwieghs the bad, you should try it. It's not a perfect game and I probably wouldn't finish it gain, but it's a unique experience.

												>inb4 new player to old style games like thisAs someone who fell in love with the series at Fallout 3 I must say this game series has come a long way. This game is very simlistic yet incredibly difficult. I cannot seem to figure out the control scheme and how to use the vats system effectively without me moving 2mph around every corner. As someone who has never played games like this and if you havent either I wouldnt recommend unless you're very committed. I give this a 3/5 as I know it's the foundation for one of my favorite series; however, with the controls and outdated format all together I cannot see a new player base for this game. PRO:Beginning to Fallout seriesProbably has decent story and good charactersCON: very outdated and extremely difficult for new playersif you've played games similar to the control scheme of this game I recommend as I'm sure it's a fantastic title. However if you're a newcomer to these older style PC games I would not recommend as they are way to outdated to truly enjoy.

content:
Posted: January 6
												I love Fallout 2 that game rocks and I really recommend playing it if you want to experience what Fallout games, in my opinion, are really meant to be. But Fallout 1... I just can't get into.(tl;dr at the bottom)My problem with Fallout one is the water chip an Item that forces you to go and find it in 150 days. In theory this sounds great, an object that forces you from one location to another in a certain amount of time that makes sure that you aren't straying. But the execution is horrible, I found myself with a crap ton of towns unlocked early into the game. This resulted in me traveling to a nearby one and finding out that a water chip "apparently" in a town that is 5 day days travel form where I currently am and resulted in me going there and finding out that there are freaking super mutants in the place in which Im searching for the water chip. So I proceed to turn around and go to the brotherhood of steel which is a 10-15 day travel from where I am as that sounds like a place where I would find a water chip. When I get there I am told to go to "The glow" which is 10 days there and 10 days back and retrieve and item. When I do that they let me in, and guess what they don't have a water chip. So now I am sitting at 53 days left as I also made Detours to other towns to do crap.tl;drBut enough rambling I will just get to the point. Fallout 2 was fun because it gave you more freedom and all the the time in the world, as thirteen years is enough to do everything in the game 5X over.Fallout 1 on the other hand, while smaller in scale forces you to play it's pace rather then yours and gives you a small amount of time to do everything. If Fallout one was my first old school Fallout game I would have just dropped the series entirely and never picked it up again.edit:spelling

content:
Posted: June 7, 2016
												Fallout is a classic Post-Apocalyptic role-playing game that took RPGing to a place other than medieval fantasy lands. It solidified the open-world genre with its highly interactive world and demonstrates an unusual amount of self-awareness.GAMEPLAY: 9/10Fallout is a game about choice. Every decision you make is acknowledged, either by scripted events or with the in-game Karma system. This game lets you do things that no other game would let you do. You can side with the main antagonist, kill children, or even complete the game without killing anybody. It's very big on the role-playing aspect and your stats matter. For example, playing as a character with low intelligence will reduce your character to a grunting idiot. It's not one of those fake RPGs where you just do the same thing over and over until you level up. In fact, grinding is pretty much absent since there are so many unique ways to gain XP. The combat system is decent but not the game's strong point. The game is full of well-written dialogue and complex conversation trees. There are many different paths to take which give the game incredible replay value. Overall, full of great non-linear gameplay. If the thought of not always knowing exactly what to do scares you, just view an online guide and you'll be fine.PRESENTATION: 7/10Fallout's graphics have aged much better than other games of the period due to using pre-rendered graphics. However, despite this, the game is still rather low-resolution and the UI is somewhat clunky. However, the sound design is excellent with great voice actors. The head models used when conversing with important characters are detailed and look pretty realistic for an old game. This game also game has excellent death animations that accurately reflect a weapon's kill power. However if you're squeamish you can change the settings to make it less gory or eliminate blood entirely. The CGI cutscenes also look great too. The music tops it all, however, with an excellent score composed by Mark Morgan.STORY: 10/10Fallout is an excellent example of combining gameplay and story. They are essentially the same thing in this game, as every action you take makes an impact on the plot. With loads of interesting characters Fallout will please fans of quality video game narratives.Overall this game is highly reccomended if you're a fan of intelligent and mature games. You don't need to be particularly intelligent to figure the game out, but you'll find you using your brain a lot more than other video games. A lot of people say it's just nostalgia, but the game was already over ten years old when I first played it, and I loved it. Definitely reccomended if you're a classic gamer or a fan of games that give you lots of choice.

content:
Posted: August 27, 2013
												[WARNING: Not a standard review, but rather a guide how to play old games when you first played newer ones, ie. Fallout 3 and New Vegas]This game came out in 1997, when I was only 2 years old. I doubt I was even self-aware back then.It won't be a surprise that I am much into newer games then. However, I like old games too, since I've been a player since I was 3 or so. However, I never had the pleasure to play any games from Fallout series until about, I guess, 2010 or 2011. The first game was Fallout 3 and the only thing that encouraged me to play this masterpiece (with flaws, bit still a masterpiece nonetheless) was the fact Bethesda Softworks made this, and I've been familiar with this company due to The Elder Scrolls. I was already a big fan of Morrowind and Oblivion back then, so I checked on (ie. downloaded it from torrents) Fallout 3, which was great, but also very black-and-white when it comes to story, moralities and taking sides.Then I checked out New Vegas. It was great, and I also noticed that it was more morally ambiguous than Fallout 3. There were much less obvious choices when it comes to what will come out of them next. I read some reviews on both games. Seemed like old veterans of Fallout series liked NV more due to it being more like previous games than Fallout 3. So I figured out that NV is somewhat like first two Fallouts, to some degree.In the meantime, while I was sucked into NV (after I bought legitimate versions of these games on Steam), I was trying to play older Fallouts (these were initially downloaded from torrents as well). Both first and second. I really tried, but couldn't do this because these games were... I don't know. Not outdated, definitely not. But definitely not as "user-friendly" as F3 and FNV. These newer Fallouts simply had more intuitive interfaces, prettier locations, simpler controls, beautiful and detailed environments and you could approach these games in many varying styles. Fallout is much more difficult, because you don't have autosaves, interface takes time to learn (especially exchanging equipment and trading), if you can do something, it is much less obvious, because it is a lot simpler to engage in straightforward combat rather than research how you can click on repair and/or sneak or science or whatever, and like Morrowind compared to Oblivion, much of combat isn't based on how skilled you are (ie. the player) at playing games and aiming, but on your character's skills and probability (ie. dice rolls). So it took me several approaches to both games (which took me several months) to try to figure these games out. I was constantly dying, I felt the pressure of time (150 days remaining before you can find the water chip for your Vault, jeez...). It was very hard to bear with.However, several days ago, original Fallouts were on sale. -75% off. Only 5€ for F1, F2 and FT. Would be a sin not to buy them. I bought them, despite the fact I knew it was very unlikely that I'd like them anyday soon.But you know, it's weird, because once you BUY something instead of getting it for free, you feel obliged to try it out even more. You feel like "for ♥♥♥♥'s sake, I paid money for it, so I MUST COMPLETE THIS GAME!".And I felt like that too. I still feel like that. It took me several months, but I ♥♥♥♥ING DID IT. I learned how to actually play this game!And I can wholeheartfully recommend it, but only if you know how it is like to play old games or if you are inhumanly persistent.

content:
Posted: June 10, 2015
												This game came out in 1997 and it surprisingly holds up to this day. I was afraid I wouldn't like it because of how old it was and that I had played Fallout 3 and New Vegas first but I was completely wrong. It's basically the same as Fallout 3 and NV but isometric. The classic Fallout charm is present in this game with a main story and a few side quests. Though the game seems kinda basic in some areas a lot of the game seems a lot deeper and more indepth than a lot of Modern RPG's. At the time I can imagine this was quite revolutionary setting the standard for RPG's in general.Only once or twice I got fustrated at the game, not due to the lack of direction but due to the logic I was using to solve a problem not working even though I felt like it should. However it turned out the thing I was doing you were actually meant to do later on but I originally didn't try it again until I looked up I was doing it correctly just in the wrong area. Oh well.As I mentioned earlier, the lack of direction is a big thing in this game. The first quest is "Find the water chip. Here is a place it MIGHT be." and that's it. It's very satisfying to complete quests because of this as you need to ask around and gather information to solve the quests for yourself.My only complaint with the game is that the combat is unforgiving and can be fustrating at times as you can get instakilled just because of a random critical hit. The accuracy is also unforgiving at times as well especially in skills that you haven' trained as much. It's not that it's stupid it's far too unforgiving for what it is.The bottom line:If you enjoyed the other Fallout games (including 3 and NV) you will like this one.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2016
												Fallout 1 is a very ♥♥♥♥ing good game. In fact, it's probably one of the best games of all time, and is definitely the best RPG ever made. Everything from the combat, which still holds up well today, to the dialogue, which is deep and satisfying with many options and even more outcomes, even to the ambient music, is perfect. Though the main allure here is the role-playing. Your stats actually matter (unlike the most recent FO games to an extent). In fact, early game your stats are the only thing that will keep you alive. If you chose wrong or without thinking, you're screwed. There are so many different outcomes to every quest and the game is very narrative-driven, but it still manages that feeling of complete player freedom that Bethesda have sacrificed so much to achieve in the newer games. Really, it's just ♥♥♥♥ing awesome. Go buy it.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2015
												Skip Fallout 3, avoid it like the plague and cancer it is to gaming as a whole. Get Fallout 1, Fallout 2, and Fallout: New Vegas.This one is the most unforgiving of the three. You're on a time limit, certain dialogue options can completely destroy your reputation in some places, resulting in death or simply being unable to continue any further conversation. The atmosphere is great, so is the story. The writing is exceptional, but nowhere nearly as good as Fallout 2 and Fallout: New Vegas. Keep in mind that while the series has always prided itself in player choices, the game kind of feels linear at the start. In fact, the dialogue is so inconsitent that it almost feels like Skyrim. The combat system is also very comfy, just turn the combat speed up a bit so you don't have to sit there for 30 minutes and stare at some cave rat walk across the run while you're trying to run away from it.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												Not as good as the second game.  Much shorter (entire playthru doing everything except grinding random encounters for hours for most is around 20 hrs), and the whole timer thing puts a damper on things.  I play RPGs to avoid quick thinking.  I do that all day.  I like to think out my moves, and the turn based combat in this game allows that.  I like to explore.  I like to take forever to actually dent the main storyline quests.  The timer kills that quite a bit.  I get what they were doing, and that sense of dread was very real.  The writing is solid obviously, Black Isle duh.  I know what the timer was there for, and can appreciate the device it represents.  Any arguments for it are valid, but I am sure glad they took it out in FO2.  Other than that play this game.  If the graphics matter to you don't, also if you are impatient.  The UI is chunky, as it should be.  I actually like it, the whole pip boy novelty is solid.  It takes a few minutes in these games to shed off the expectation of convenience I get from the newer games today.  Not necessarily quest markers, or quest info even, but more ease of operation.  You gotta try things till they work in these games.  I like this.  Takes me  a few minutes to realize, but the wastelands are so harsh, even the game's ui fights you.  The hostility is palpable, and it is entirely worth it.  Who needs fast travel quest marker quests, banging out 5 at a time, when you could literally spend an hour pixel hunting, trying out different skills, talking to npcs, trying anything to avoid having to shoot up the place and make your life a ton harder.  All this just to get that one part you need, to trade for that other one part you need, so the guy who you are getting said part for will just give you bad information.  PLEASANTLY frustrating! :)

content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												I want so bad to give this game a good review. I really do. I like this game, for the most part. But let's be honest here, it hasn't aged well at all. There is a lack of control over your other characters that is just horrible. There's a severe lack of balance in the way damage is delt. The way you interface with the game is probably my biggest problem, it makes the game practically unplayable. Everything is slow and delayed. I'm not recommending this game, don't misunderstand my intentions here. I'm not recommending the game because it's a good game, by 1997 standards. It's a classic, and it runs like a classic, that's been horribly neglected. This game really needs a remaster. A facelift and some adjustments to the controls, some minor adjustments to how your followers interact with you and you'll have something really great. As it stands though I just can't recommend it. It will be more frustration than fun. I do love the depth of the game, it's really great. And if it's on sale grab it, you might enjoy it, otherwise I think I'd look for something else. It pains me to hit the thumbs down button here but as it stands I feel this game provides more frustration than fun. I've spent more time waiting on screens to open and close and waiting on my items to switch than I have actually playing it. Here's hoping for that remaster.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
												This is not like Fallout 3 or New Vegas. This game is tough especially for people who are not experienced in cRPGS. With that being said, this game is enjoyable- i clocked in about 25 hours. This game has many problems - bugs, broken and cut quests, outdated graphics(even with highrez mod), not fully fledged or connecting dialogue, outdated gameplay mechanics, having to optimize this game for your comp by yourself(THANKS STEAM...) and my main gripe that this game feels to me a beta for fallout 2 which most people say is the superior between the two.I feel this game gets the classic nod, because of what it brings to the western rpg genre  - a unique rpg system with perks, special stats and skills which affect the world around you, ambigous morality, interesting setting and lore, great story line, fairly good dialogue, random encounters.AS a person who's first fallout game was New Vegas, i felt really out of place when i first dl this game. Its really difference and theirs a learning curve to it.This game is old and outdated - this is true no argument about that. So it will affect my final score.My Score system: 10/10 is a perect, 5/10 is average, and 0/10 Horrible.This game is a 7/10, a good game. It should be played if your a fallout fan and have never touched this old cRPG classic.

number of helpful: 7 of 20 people (35%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 21, 2015
												Well, at least I can tell myself that I tried. After hearing around the whole internet that this game was definetly better than Fallout 3 and on, I decided to buy it. I was sure that the game would have some pretty bad graphics and what not, but personally I don't mind old games and bad graphix at all. What a game should have, its value. A game with a good story, a good gameplay. and a good fluidity , it's a good game. Fallout 1 only gets the story characteristic right. Yes, the story is amaing, and t gets the feeling and atmosphere right. It was amazing to get inmersed into the wasteland for the first time, but, that's about it. Honestly, even modern Fallouts get this right. The problem with this game is the gameplay, and the pacing. My god.    The gameplay is horrible. It is so slow, and ridiclous, that it makes it boring. It's basicaly a point and click battle system, with enemies that deal ridiculous damage and never miss, while you are too weak and are constantly missing.   It never made me feel good, like an RPG usually does, about getting stronger with EXP., and then tackling the stronger enemies and achieving victories. Why? cause, and this is the best part, at the beginning of the game, you have a stupid time limit. You can't go around exploring the wasteland and getting stronger at your own pace! Nope. You need to hurry and finish part of the main quest with as little moves as possible, so you don't get a game over. If you are like me and you don't like looking up things at google to solve games, then you'll probably have to start over from scratch more than once to figure out what to do to solve this problem. It's just not fun. Anybody that likes this game is because they feel nostalgia. That's it. The game itsef is garbage, quite honestly. Every single character is shallow, except for the final boss, and the side-quest are crap. If you lived in the 80's and 90's this game would've been mind blowing. Today, it's crap.

number of helpful: 2 of 10 people (20%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 12
												A classic in all regards I must say: gameplay, presentation, and story. Also when it comes to classics, however; an obtrusive control interface and mechanics that don't work in modern times. I've been a big fan of the Fallout franchise for at least 9 years at this point, my obsession starting with Fallout 3. A game that I believe still holds up quite well, same goes with New Vegas (the sort of actual sequel to Fallout 1 and 2). Although 3 and New Vegas have their problems, with their clunky combat system and more bugs than a cabbage field that hasn't been sprayed with pesticide, are what I classify as fun. Fallout 1, is not fun. As I mentioned earlier, it's controls are garbage and hard to get a hold of today and certainly was a niche for certain people back in day (I presume at least, I was born a year after the game came out.) Maybe I'm spoiled, I probably am, but the way you go about ANYTHING in Fallout 1 isn't intuitive in the slightest. Wanna check out that body? Right click mouse over the body, hold the left click down, and then move the mouse down to examine the body. Wanna hack a computer? Click on the red button at the far right of your interface and click "Science" and you'll get a yellow crosshair. Mouse the crosshair over the computer and HOPE you hack it. Hacking/lockpicking/any sort of skill check is asinine. You never get any indication of how tough a skillcheck will be unless you try to bash your head against it until you break the lock, get locked out of the computer, or magically it works. Combat I'm very split on. When you don't break your gun, drop your weapon, stab yourself, or miss, combat can be decent at times. Although even in a full suit of power armor, you can magically get one shotted by super mutants because...because. Fighting in enclosed locations is a hassle as well, since sometimes you can't see what position your enemy is at so sometimes your shot may be blocked so you have to use up precious action points to get an angle on them. Companions are also a detrement in combat, since they can miss and end up shooting you, getting a critical hit, and kill you. Thanks Ian. Other times they bug out if they run out of ammo, and ditch their gun. Even after giving them extra ammo, they never reverted back to their guns and only used a knife or just never ever fought any enemies ever again. I had to make 5 characters because each time I ran out of the very stupid time limit that's forced on you at the start of the game. Oh about that, this game is an semi-open world RPG with a TIME LIMIT. You have 150 days to get a water chip for your vault or else it's instant game over. 150 days sounds like a lot, but it really isn't. You'll use up those days trying to find a god damn piece of rope you need to travel down another vault to get said water chip. At least once you get the water chip, the time limit is gone. Looting is a pain if you're running with laser weaponry too, since you end up vaporizing your enemies who drop all their goodies on the ground. You have to individually mouse over items to pick them up, and sometimes items are so small, you miss them. I had to reload a save that was hours back, just to get a item I needed to complete the game with.tl;dr/wrap upFallout 1 can be fun at times. Most times however, it isn't fun at all. It's aged poorly, has a terrible interface, and has really dumb, easy to miss plot crucial items. It's neat to see where the series started, but I'd stick with any of the newer games.

number of helpful: 6 of 20 people (30%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 27, 2016
												The short version would be for you to get an upgraded experience from Fallout 2 and read about this one on the wikipedia or something.So this game has a lot of fan boys... This game suffers from serious gameplay drawbacks that make it more frustrating than fun. Like seriously I think a 5 year old could have designed better math models for the hit percentages in this game. Seriously, I had VATS 87% chance to hit then shoot and miss 18 times in a row. Guess what game... that's not an 87% chance. Now if this happened once or twice, ok that's one thing, but this is a constant fight the game puts you against for no reason.Next is the criticals... worst experience with them ever. After the first quarter of the game they will be the only enemy attack that will kill you. The normal attacks will hit you for 0 HP continuously, but then a mole rat will crit you for over 110 HP. The last boss is a perfect example of this. Him and his Super Mutants regular damage 0 HP lost, then a critical 200 HP lost. Your life will depend on a critical attack every turn of every encounter. Dreadul to a mathematical power of 50.Then there's a mixture of feelings when it comes to the stories and plot in the game. The NPC's are pretty deep and well planned out. They offer information on the world, and allow you to see a sort of cultural element to the Wasteland. I liked this alot, and the locations you do get to visit are unique and inspiring. Yet in the end they are far to sparse to really feel connected to. Then the map... oh god the map... You will waste most of your time traveling into areas that will never lead to anywhere. Then in a moment you will realize that 80% of the map is dead, worthless space. Thanks for wasting my time game walking through desert fighting mole rats for absolutely nothing.These combinations of bad gameplay make this a terrible game, but a great story. That's why I recommend reading on this one then moving to the second one. Nearly all of the problems in gameplay this faces are rectified in the second. Making Fallout 2 a much better choice for your money.

content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
												I never thought that a classic game such as this would be so bad.I really wanted to play this for the story but man this just isn't worth it. If you genuinely think this is a 10/10 game you must have been 10 years old when you last played this. Nostalgia has to be the only cure for this.As I'm writing this I just finally ragequit after playing an 9 hour session, in the middle of which I had to start a new character because I found out that I had basically just lost the game there and there was no way to return. The reason I just ragequit is that pretty much the same thing happened again. I went into an area from which I could not get out alive. Of course I only had one save because I couldn't ever have expected ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t like this.The game forces you to save every 5 seconds because you never know when YOU are going to ♥♥♥♥ YOURSELF over by choosing one of the wrong answers in some conversation (even though it might be a completely normal thing to say).If you fail to choose the "right" thing to say from the 4 or 5 dialogue options some NPCs will NEVER TALK TO YOU AGAIN. Their hatred for you burns with the heat of the sun because you asked how they were doing instead of if they had a job for you.The NPCs also seem to ignore the stats that bind the player. They shoot you with ♥♥♥♥♥♥ starting pistols from a mile away and do damage you can only dream of doing yourself.Other than that the combat mechanics are pretty interesting and work well. You can plan your moves well and do some really nice tacticool stuff. It was really satisfying to clear out the Raider Camp but after meeting Super Mutants and finding out that they have infinite health I just didn't know what the hell I was supposed to do to get more levels.Some of the objectives were also almost impossible to find out for yourself. Sometimes there is a pixel-fine line between advancing to the next area and "nothing interesting happens". I only checked a guide once to see what to do next and I am sure I would have been there for two hours and restarted the whole game after that if I didn't do it.Maybe it was all my fault and I'm really bad at video games. But damn this game isn't hard, it's ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. Mechanical difficulty is entirely different from what this game is.Don't buy this game if you want to find out about the Fallout story. Just go read it.

content:
Posted: August 15, 2014
												Don't bother purchasing Fallout, if you're interested in the older installments purchase Fallout 2. The game is riddled with bugs, so don't bother playing it without the Fallout FIXD Mod.  The actual game itself leaves a lot to be desired, as the gameplay and story are paper thin.  Most perks and skills are useless in the game, so you'll likely need to read up on how to build your character before you begin playing, so as to not put yourself at a major disadvantage at the onset.  This is extremely dissapointing for an RPG game, as it forces you to play in a certain way, not the way you want to play.  The world is small, and main baddies (super mutants), play almost no role in the game, save one instance, until the finale.  The controls take a few hours to get used to, but even after a day of playing, you may still be unsure how to approach certain quests and objectives presented within the game.  (You need to "use" a radio to disable the forcefields at the military base, wah?, and good luck figuring that out without using google.)   There's little reason to explore quests on the side, some are only initiated with very specific dialouge (despite it seeming as though you've reached an agreement), and some quests are hinted at but don't even exist at all!  The rewards that come from completing the various quests are useless unless there's some type of loot you'll find along the way.  Don't bother saving up money to purchase the various in game weapons, as you'll find all the ammo and weaponry you need along the way.  There are only a few talking heads in the game, but other than the Mutant at the military base and the "Master" during the end-game, the characters are bland, boring, and offer little in the way of interesting information or background.  All of this takes away from the games interesting premise that paved the way for much better Fallout sequels.   Towards the end of the game, I finally realized that there's little meaningful dialogue and reason to explore the map and grinded through it, only to have the game crash at the end.  Good aspects of the game include the excellent voice acting (despite most of it being shallow), and a few interesting story bits provided by the two meaningful characters.  The combat can also be fun in final stages of the game, but boring at the beggining and middle portions.  Overall the atmosphere and originality of the game and its sequels makes the games existence seem worthwhile.  However, as a standalone game it has little redeeming qualities, and at the insanely rip-off price of $10, you're better off watching the cutscenes on Youtube and passing on this so call "classic".

Posted: July 30, 2014
												I had high hopes in this legendary game, and was terribly disappointed.From the beginning, the game plays extremely slow and felt more like work than like fun. I seriously had to force myself to keep playing the game, and if i hadnt paid for it, i would have already deinstalled it!About the reasons: The difficulty is extremely hard, as the hero is very weak, and hardly able to kill anything at the beginning. Be prepared to reload very often, as random encounters are usually much more than you could take, and as the leveling process is painfully slow!Then, as you would expect from such an old game, the graphic is terrible, and the game mechanics are outdated. Dont expect the comfort, complexity and polish of modern games. Without fanmods, this game is hardly playable at all, and even with, the game crashes constantly and lots of bugs remain. And finally, there is a time-limit for your mission, which causes a tough game to become stressy and annoying.Personally, i cannot recommend this game at all!

content:
Posted: June 8, 2015
												Disclaimer: I have previously played Fallout 3 and enjoyed both the game and universe. That being said, I looked into the original games a bit before purchasing to see what type of gameplay it was.The Basics:  This game has a top-down view with turn-based combat. The game came out in 1997, so the graphics are starting to show their age.My Opinion: I didn't care for this game at all. There are two big things that ruined the game for me: poor direction and terrible combat. When it comes to quests, I would like some for of, "the main mission/quest is in this general direction." I want some idea of knowing how I can progress. I am not asking for the game to hold my hand. I actually don't care for games that hold my hand. However, I shouldn't have to look at a walkthrough to tell me where I have to go for the main story. It would be one thing if I didn't know where to find a side mission/quest. Sometimes people get lost in games, sure. You start out lost at the beginning of the game with no sense of direction in a cave. The combat was the second issue I had. It's clunky and bland. Maybe I just didn't play far enough into the game, but it just felt sloppy and wasn't engaging. It didn't feel like I was able to do anything. You start off with all of your items, and weapons, in your bag. You have nothing equpped. Take a few steps forward and you are in your first battle. Now, almost every single game I have ever played has you start with a weapon equipped, or you fight to gain that first weapon. As I said, you have your first weapon, why the hell is it not equipped or tell you to check inventory? So after you either fail or realize, "oh hey, I have a ♥♥♥♥ing gun that nobody told me about," you finally equip it. Now you can fight rats and point blank range with a gun. You shoot, you miss. You shoot again, you miss again. Meanwhile, this rat is going to beat the hell out of you and you lose half of your health while shooting and outline of the rat around him.Conclusion: This game isn't for me. The sloppy direction and combat are what drove me away. Maybe the game is too dated. Maybe if I had tried it a few years soon, I might have been able to enjoy it. The fact is that now I don't find the game enjoyable at all.3/10

content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												Ah, the original Fallout. One of the classic RPGs that's generally (and unfortunately) overlooked by people today.This game would be slightly better if the port was updated to the point where it wasn't so glitchy. First of all, the cutscenes are very blurry and rainbow-y. Second, there is no sort of instruction at all (which isn't Steam's fault, the only instructions that came with this game originally came in the manual booklet). Thirdly, there's few to no options with which to change resolution or full-screen/window.The game itself is much more difficult than I expected, which is neither a plus nor a minus. Some games are harder than others, so what?Honestly, while I like the game, I don't really recommend buying it unless you're willing to fix the bugs and learn to play completely by yourself.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2014
												Really slow and quite boring to play. Since I played the newer games first I probably grew to expect fast paced combat in all the games, but instead you get slow, and I mean SLOW, turned based combat. The action point system really annoys me as well, Ive got like a 9 out of 10 for agility or endurance (or whatever) in my stats which I expected, like in the newer games, would make me run faster and for longer but Ive got like 10 "action points" instead which I know sounds big and you think you might be able to do loads of stuff with them, but each 'action' takes about 3 or 4 points, so you end up only being able to do like 2 things per turn. Oh and by action, I mean: Walk around, look in inventory (which takes 3 action points by the way), shoot/attack something, look at something, or literally anything really. So when compared to the incredibly slow combat, with you maybe, (if your lucky) getting 2 shots, or attacks, on an enemy each turn, you get an even more slow and boring game.The story isnt that great also. All you need to do is get a water chip or something so your told to go to another vault and find one, so then when you get there you're literally just told: "OH ITS NOT HERE, PROBABLY SOMEWHERE ELSE THEN". I got bored after that and just stopped. The game makes me feel really tired, honestly about 30 minutes of gameplay and I need to quit otherwise I might fall asleep. I know that Im being harsh but because I grew with the newer generation Fallout games like Fallout 3 and New Vegas I felt really disappointed by this one. This is just my opinion by the way but if you do get bored quickly and if you hate slow gameplay then this is NOT the game for you. I give it about 4.5/10

content:
Posted: November 20, 2016
												It didn't take long to decide I didn't like this game. The menus are fiddley.Locations are hidden behind walls until you move a character there.The real dealbreaker, however, is the combat.  You have to move a character to the edge of the map to end a fight, such as when you have a random encounter with "radscorpions" that you can't deal damage against.  I encountered such a situation and while I moved my main character (who is the only one in your control, by the way) to the edge of the map to flee the scorpions chased my ally off the the screen and then killed him.  Again... they were fighting off screen!The entire combat system is overly simple to begin with:  Use action points to move, shoot, reload, switch weapons or use a healing item.  You can only do maybe two per turn.In short, combat which is half the game is a complete joke.  Don't waste your money.

												If you're buying this, just know it has a sħitty mechanic where the game ends (wont let you keep playing) abruptly if you take too long to find the water chip or just dont care about finding it like i did, THATS RIGHT, this crap game will throw away all your progress just because you either didn't care for the main story or was too busy grinding, why this game wont let you play after your vault dies is beyond me other than the fact that interplay is probably braindead, I shouldn't have to make a new save just because i don't care about the water chip. 6 hours of progress gone just because i wanted to grind so that i would actually stand a chance against tougher enemies. Thank's interplay.Update: Just got done playing fallout 2, it's even worse. It forces you to have 4 intelligence or more to beat the game (You can't find vault 13 without it) and have a melee build at the start of the game or you can't win the fist fight with the guy at the end of temple of trials (Basically you can't progress and you're forced to make a new character). Speaking of the temple of trials, you can't skip it, even if your character has 10 intelligence and charisma you can't convice the guy outside the temple to move out of the way, same for the guy at the end of the temple, nice immersion interplay. And if your character has three intelligence or less, good luck finding a cure for jet addiction. This game is so bad it makes fallout seem good in comparison, atleast in fallout you can beat the game with a low intelligence character, with any build, And theres no forced/scripted events that you can't skip or intervene in. If there's anything good i can say about fallout, it's that atleast it's not fallout 2.

Posted: June 24, 2016
												Awful game. History is pretty good and the concept of a post-apocalyptic lone survivor in the future is something we saw in Mad Max and we know we love it. But the commands and controls are beyond bad and incomprehensible even after an hour or 2 playing. Only way you can walk is by using walking points, the only way to attack is by using action points and if you get surrounded by enemies and there are no action points left (meaning you cant attack) you'll be stuck eternally LOL laughable engine material. This game apparently was made by some lunatic Dungeons & Dragons fan who wanted to f*ck you up and give you a hard time so you'd know what's it to be a total nerd who has no idea of what a life or a p*ssy is. Don't get me wrong, I personally love the story of the game and the concept. Fallout 3 was a great reinvention of the series but this is just outrageous and unnaceptable. Made for a different era and for people with special needs. Just don't buy it. Not worth a penny.

Posted: November 30, 2013
												A classic, plain and simple. Its a merciless game but, intensely addicting. Vastly different play style than from Fallout 3 and New Vegas, its a third person view turn based combat, there are plenty of fights you'll encounter that require a good deal of planning. The storyline is shorter compaired to the other games but eacht ime you play the experience is completely different based on your SPECIAL stats. The only downside is this has trouble running on current machines, I tracked down some patches that fix it but still run into some issues with stability. This of course is to be expected from an older game.

content:
Posted: November 19, 2015
												This is a very, very thick game.The amount of RPG and options is mass, and the different storylines and endings are quite fun to accomplish. Hell, I lost A WEEK AND A HALF PLAYING THIS. Look at my hours clocked!Where can I start. Ever played S.T.A.L.K.E.R.? Imagine that but in a top-down shooter, with thicker character traits that can help or kill your plight into the Wastelands.You start off in the remains of California after a generation passed, following the Great War. There's so much to explore and so much to do that I cannot put it all into one review.Things I liked the most were the replayability, the charcters, the dialogue, the content, the setting, the sheer fun of getting drunk and shooting Bandits and Raiders and Monsters. Depending on how you're built, you can decide just who accompanies you, what you do, when you do it and where. You can take jobs, continue with the quest, become a breeki, so much to do.Take a look for yourself, be warned, spoilers ahead.


YouTube™ Video: Fallout Soundtrack  (PC) 

			Views: 86,477		

			By Mark Morgan. Track list: Maybe, a song by The Ink Spots 01 - Metallic Monks (Lost Hills) 02 - Desert Wind (the Wasteland) 03 - A Trader's Life (the Hub) 04 - The Vault of the Future (Vault 13) 05...		

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=558274240http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=558274832http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=558276484http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=558274768Things I didn't like were the controls, the fact you REALLY have to read EVERYTHING that's in .pdf or .word in the Game Directory in order to know what the hell is going on. Then there's also this: http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=558257959 That I probably would have remembered, had I re-read the manual.Over all, the rating should be a 90-92 but the critics do have their merit. If you never played Fallout before, this is the game to start. If the angle and the controls are too clonky for you, I highly recommend starting in New Vegas or better yet, Fallout 4.http://store.steampowered.com/app/22380http://store.steampowered.com/app/377160/Be warned, you WILL miss out on a lot of story and that's just what I loved about this game. Also if you decide to buy, I'd recommend this: http://store.steampowered.com/sub/45615/ Over just Fallout by itself. Unless you're really unsure, then just grab this one!I can't wait to get to 4, just now beat the game and after some going back to goof around, gonna work my way up to the big ones.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 5, 2015
												What can be said about this classic masterpiece, that hasn't been said already? if you never played Fallout, you might be wondering if "it is really that good, or it is just nostalgia". The short answer is yes, it is incredibly good. It is easily one of the best 5 RPGs ever released.I'll start with the aspects of the game that may not be that good. Inventory management is cumbersome, as you can only view a few items at the same time and have to scroll up and down constantly. Overall the UI is not as "comfortable" to use as modern UIs. Also, the enemy AI is a bit primitive (not that newer games are any better, actually...) and you'll also find that some character development options are obvious "traps" that may make you restart the game. for instance, there's certain skills that you can raise easily spending money in-game; if you don't know that and spend your valuable points there, you'll seriously handicap yourself. Same with some weapon skill choices. Finally, companions are rather weak, since you can't equip them nor they seem to progress nor follow any orders; they are fragile and suicidal, so in the endgame you're better off without them. Now that the "not perfect" things are out of the way, let's get to the meaty part.The setting and the whole idea about Fallout is brilliant, and has been executed perfectly, much better depicted and detailed than in the new Bethesda sequels. Dialogues are short yet well-written, the layout and pacing of the story makes sense, and the atmosphere when you explore places like Vault 15 or The Glow absolutely delivers. The game can feel oppresive and dark when it wants to, yet there is plenty of humor that even breaks the "fourth wall" sometimes, and it has been added with good taste, so it doesn't erode the game's apocalyptic atmosphere.Quests in this game put to shame most of the quest writers in this generation. So many different ways to solve them! and no, I don't mean the trivial meaningless choices for one reward or another you see in Skyrim; I mean that you can solve almost all the situations without violence, and you can make choices that really alter the world. There's a "dumb way", a "talky way", "sneaky way" to solve each problem, to a degree like no other RPG I can think of. This variety of choice is the essence of RPGs, what really makes you feel like you are "playing a role" in a unique way, different from what other players did. One of the reasons Fallout is so immersive is because it really brings on the table the element of survival. Unlike in most RPGs, where you quickly escalate the curve of power and become invulnerable, you can be easily killed in Fallout, always. Friendly fire is always a big risk, and even in the end game, and having good weapons and armor, you can get shot down rather quickly if your strategy is bad. Which encourages thinking, and caring. Survival becomes the main focus in the game, which is quite amazing. The moment you begin feeling "safe" in a setting like this, you can say that it has failed to deliver.Yet, once you understand the tactical elements in the game, it is not that hard. Difficulty is very well gauged in my opinion, punishing you when you are reckless or pick the wrong fights, yet allowing you to gain advantage when you do things right and choose the right tools for each job. As it should be.There's many more aspects I could talk about, I suppose. Sound and music are good, art is sometimes outstanding, sometimes adequate. Overland map allows to travel in a non-cumbersome way, without losing the feeling of "exploration". And the details make obvious this game was made with love and patience. Little things like weapon descriptions, or small humorous references in dialogues, or some of the random encounters. Classy. Timeless. 10/10. Must play if you love the genre.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 8, 2015
												I completely missed the older installments of Fallout like many fans; I didn't pick up the series until Fallout 3 and had little knowledge of the predecessors. The gameplay is vastly different, but I was pleasantly surprised and love how the theme and culture of the game really did ring through the series. I was in awe about how great the atmosphere of this game is; the music, brutality, twists, and the little tidbits that make it a great RPG. Granted, it's from 1997 so the expansive of the game was obviously limited by capabilities at the time.  Despite of that however... this game can get you addicted and playing for many hours! Leaving you begging for more and you understand why it's a series. I highly recommend this game if you're a fan of Fallout theme; post-apocalypse, gritty realities, gory outcomes, and a moral compass thrown out the window. You'll fall in love with the towns, people, missions, and the outcomes that directly correlate to what you do. The action in this game is oriented toward classic RPGs; it is turn/dice roll statistics dependent. So you won't be running around... but you'll question your sanity when you smile every time an enemy's torso blows in half from a critical hit. You'll get 20+ hours of gameplay from this game if you play the main storyline and do the essential/big missions. I imagine there's much more to the game that I missed during my playthrough. Buy it. Enjoy it. And smile knowing there's sequels waiting for you.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
												Fallout 1 and 2 are the greatest RPGs of all time.  Bugs, fairly clunky interface and controls, turn-based combat and all.  The game draws you in, and won't let go even after multiple playthroughs; and on that note, this game is one of the most replayable of all time.  The depth and flexabilty of this masterpiece rival any RPG.  Stealth is well implimented, hand to hand combat is very distinct from ranged, and diplomacy and deception will often avert the necesity for combat at all, allowing players to possibly avoid combat completely (as boring as that sounds).But is the combat fun?  I mean turn-based combat sounds fairly tedious in todays generation of fast-paced gaming right?  Surprisingly (for an ADD guy like myself) the turn-based combat here is incredibly addicting, with each and every action point precious and not to be tossed off lightly!  For some gamers, the combat will certainly be too in depth, and simply not within the range of their gaming interest, but many would be surprised if they gave this gem a chance.The writing is excellent, and I'm not an easy sell.  But the voice acting is probably the best ever in a video game.  I know, I know, sounds like an over-zealous fanboy, but... the voice cast is almost universally professional actors, with the great Jim Cummings edging out the rest in quality.  His three distict characters (Gizmo, The Master, and Set) are performed so well, that they are some of the few game performances I'll sit back and listen to without reflexivly skipping past.  They're that good.And one final note.  The game designers took the time to include a very unique feature, the dumb character.  If you choose to create a character with intelligence 3 or fewer, he will be an effectivly mentally challenged character, unable to converse fully with npc's.  This provides a new challenge, very different from a game with an intelligent character.  Sounds novel, I know, but the game creators literally made every single npc react to such a character as they would to a incredible dumb person, witch is often very funny (and difficult) as you will be unable to aquire many quests.Anyway, as you can tell I love this game, and highly recommend it to any and all RPG fans.  Believe me, if you give this game a shot, chances are you'll have a great time.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												If you haven't played Fallout 3 already, you're missing out. So not playing this might as well be the same thing. A top down mix of real time combat and turn based, Fallout will imerse you into the game GREATLY. I mean seriously, you can right click and hover your mouse cursor over anything and you get a detailed discription of it, then you can even left click to get an even MORE detailed description of it. The music is usually dark in most cases, kinda makes you feel like when the npcs' say, "It's dangerous there!" You feel like it's actually dangerous there. And speaking of danger, THIS GAME IS DIFFACULT. Half the time you die you don't even know the reason! Moving on to weapons and armor. New weapons and armor are quite rare, so actually finding a new weapon makes you feel great for finding it. I personally love this game, but it requires a lot of time, a lot of saving and a lot of imersing yourself into it, kinda making yourself feel like you are actually you in the game. I give it a 9/10. (Also there are a TON of easter eggs in the game that give you a fun challenge to do if you're bored; which you won't be with this game :D )
