content:
Posted: July 17, 2015
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lcLUcvXREHEAfter playing and beating this absolute masterpiece for the hundredth time, an urge to write a review about it arose within of me. The reason why i decided to write this review is so that newer players (specifically, newer Fallout fans) could get a clear picture as to what this game really is. An intention to place emphasis on this RPG's stronger and weaker aspects is present in the review (fortunately there is significantly more of the former than the latter), as well as some inevitable spoilers, so read at your own consideration!  Fallout: A Post Nuclear Role Playing Game, today known simply as Fallout 1, in my opinion, is a game which is far beyond any rating, even the most highest one. The reason for this lies in the fact that Fallout 1, being the first in the series, gave a solid start to an awesome franchise which today, with the upcoming Fallout 4, stirred up an unbelievable scope of agitation. All of the subsequent Fallout games which were released after Fallout 1 had the same majority of concepts and design, which once again proves - original and good things are difficult to create, but can last virtually forever as great success. Today, most, if not all concepts which were present in the first Fallout can be seen in the newer Fallout titles (Brotherhood of Steel initiates getting blown up in a Vertibird by the  protagonist in the Fallout 4 trailer is a good example of this). This simply goes to show, that the original Fallout isn't merely a game, it's an expertly designed world which was created in the distant 1997 and is being graphically refined up to this day. What the original Fallout 1 (and 2 for that matter) definitely had is an indescribable atmosphere and spirit around it, something which can't be brought into a video game simply via graphics and todays technological marvels. Younger players often tend to judge a title by it's visual qualities, and frankly speaking, a video game which is 18 years old cannot possibly meet modern graphical standards. I first discovered Fallout thanks to a good friend of mine, when he was playing it at his place back in 2002. By that time, Fallout was five years years old, and during those days, i have already seen and played some newer games like Jagged Alliance 2 or Diablo II:Lord of Destruction, and found these games to be somewhat more graphically advanced. Both of these titles could of been visually compared to Fallout since they share isometric, birds view graphics. At first, i found the graphics in Fallout 1 & 2 to be bleak and somewhat devoid of color, so the first impression  of the game wasn't the most positive one, although i instantly noticed it's brutal, apocalyptic style. After i immersed myself into Fallout i realized, that the designers made the game with such somber colors intentionally, since this way they could portray a more realistic, grim atmosphere set in a broken world... At that time, such design and setting was was very original and uncommon, for we gamers were all well familiar with, for an example, a fantasy setting full of orcs and dragons and magic, but no one had the pleasure to blaze lead or laser beams at huge, hulking atrocities known as Super Mutants or steal bottle caps from unaware wastelanders, or explore a huge, adventure and danger filled world with full freedom, being restricted only by a certain time limit. Despite the fact that the graphics in Fallout are outdated, the amount of detail which the developers added to this game arouses a feeling of admiration. The in-game UI visuals resemble equipment, possibly or even probably an extension of the pip-boy which the protagonist is wearing, and indicate any information regarding the world around the player. The game features a wide arsenal of weaponry, each gun has background description related to it, as does armor and other items. The surrounding  environment is somewhat repetitive but by no means boring. The game takes place in post-war state of California, which is now a barren wasteland that will always accompany you during the course of your adventures. Besides the wasteland, your character will also see many other places and environments, such as mountaincaverns or the interiors of pre-war installations. Combat animations in-game are absolutely stunning and full of gore, your enemies die in the most bloodiest of ways, as does your protagonist, if you get him killed... The atmosphere in the game is very ambient and complemented by one of the best video game OST which i have ever  heard. Most of these soundtracks were written by Mark Morgan and made their way straight into Fallout: New Vegas.The storyline in Fallout 1 can fit into many genres at once, it's an action-adventure, to a certain extent with elements of mystery and even horror (Masters Lair, anybody?) I won't ruin your gameplay by writing too much spoilers, but all i can say is that in Fallout, the lives of many people depend on the actions of your protagonist, but at the same time, he has the freedom of choice to follow the path he pleases or sees as the most  right one. There are many interesting and memorable factions and NPC's present in the game, and during the course of your adventures, your actions will affect those around you. The player can often choose between morally right and wrong decisions whilst performing side-quests, and has the freedom to travel between locations in any order he pleases. The S.P.E.C.I.A.L system which many are familiar with from Fallout 3 or NV is also present in Fallout 1 and allows the player to choose between three premade characters with their unique background stories and perks or make a custom characters and pick all of the perks and stats for him manually. One of the more annoying things younger players might find in Fallout 1 is the combat structure, or more specifically, the critical hit system. If your planning to beat Fallout 1 by means of direct combat approach (the game provides multiple approaches in order to beat it) you must assure yourself that your hero is going to die at least good few dozen times. The aforementioned critical hits in Fallout are absolutely ruthless and unbalanced, towards both you and the enemy. Wearing the best possible armor with a conjunction with a few Psycho chems for damage resistance will do little against a critical hit from a Super Mutant Minigun or a Deathclaws strike, and you will quickly see your hero either being shredded to pieces or being clawed to death even while wearing Power Armor. Engagement with enemy, aside from being at times disbalanced, is nonetheless cool, challanging and will fit your liking if your into turn based combat while drinking a cup of tea or a coffee. If your more of a Call of Duty fan though, and waiting isn't your thing, id suggest sticking to Fallout 3 or NV, on account of that they both possesses an element of a shooter, not just a turn based RPG. Fallout 1 deserves to be played and deserves to be admired, because even though it's an outdated game, it's the foundation of the whole franchise in terms of both lore and mechanics. The game also possesses great replayability, which means that you can basically beat it ten times and still miss a thing or two. I recommend Fallout 1 first and foremost to Fallout fans and those players who like old-school gaming. Secondly, i recommend Fallout to anyone who likes RPG's, although i do warn you, if your into newer games and won't cope with the restrictions of the old school graphics and gameplay, feel free to whistle a tune and pass on by, theres nothing to see here' friend.

content:
Posted: March 11
												Fallout is such a wonderful game! I love how Interplay Studios made Fallout's graphics so cool! And how Interplay Studios had come up with so many ideas for Fallout, such as the Brotherhood of Steel and their Power Armor, Vault 13 and the Vault Dweller. I used my imagination for the game, pretending that the three pre-made characters knew each other. The ending was cool, especially when you see your character leaving the vault. Fallout will forever be my Number 1 favorite game series in the world! If I was in the world of Fallout, I'd be the Vault Dweller, a teenage boy of course, not an adult. It's pretty cool how Interplay Studios made the setting take place in the 22nd century, and how they were able to make future objects such as the Power Armor, the Stealth Boy 3001, the Laser and the Plasma Rifles, et cetera. And the characters like the ghouls, the Super Mutants, et cetera. It took a lot of time and patience to make Fallout come to life! Thank you Interplay Studios for making Fallout, and thank you Brian Fargo for creating and thinking about Fallout as your idea! I look forward to more Fallout games to come! Thanks for giving me the time to review on Fallout! "War, war never changes."

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
												Fallout 1 and 2 are the greatest RPGs of all time.  Bugs, fairly clunky interface and controls, turn-based combat and all.  The game draws you in, and won't let go even after multiple playthroughs; and on that note, this game is one of the most replayable of all time.  The depth and flexabilty of this masterpiece rival any RPG.  Stealth is well implimented, hand to hand combat is very distinct from ranged, and diplomacy and deception will often avert the necesity for combat at all, allowing players to possibly avoid combat completely (as boring as that sounds).But is the combat fun?  I mean turn-based combat sounds fairly tedious in todays generation of fast-paced gaming right?  Surprisingly (for an ADD guy like myself) the turn-based combat here is incredibly addicting, with each and every action point precious and not to be tossed off lightly!  For some gamers, the combat will certainly be too in depth, and simply not within the range of their gaming interest, but many would be surprised if they gave this gem a chance.The writing is excellent, and I'm not an easy sell.  But the voice acting is probably the best ever in a video game.  I know, I know, sounds like an over-zealous fanboy, but... the voice cast is almost universally professional actors, with the great Jim Cummings edging out the rest in quality.  His three distict characters (Gizmo, The Master, and Set) are performed so well, that they are some of the few game performances I'll sit back and listen to without reflexivly skipping past.  They're that good.And one final note.  The game designers took the time to include a very unique feature, the dumb character.  If you choose to create a character with intelligence 3 or fewer, he will be an effectivly mentally challenged character, unable to converse fully with npc's.  This provides a new challenge, very different from a game with an intelligent character.  Sounds novel, I know, but the game creators literally made every single npc react to such a character as they would to a incredible dumb person, witch is often very funny (and difficult) as you will be unable to aquire many quests.Anyway, as you can tell I love this game, and highly recommend it to any and all RPG fans.  Believe me, if you give this game a shot, chances are you'll have a great time.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												Fallout will please roleplaying fans everywhere. Set in a post apocalyptic world, Fallout starts out with you (the hero) leaving the safety of your underground village to search for a water purifier which is essential for the continued survival of your village.The outer world has a similar feeling to the 'MAD MAX' movies without the cars. Through many towns you interact with seperate factions and gangs, often invoving your self in quests, or trying to avoid being killed!You can design your own character or use a predesigned character. You have several statistics which combined with some 'characteristics' give you a list of percentile abilities (e.g. small gun 65% - meaning you have a 65% chance of hitting an enemy in normal conditions!).The world is set out in several sections. Based on a vast grid, you have many wilderness boxes and several 'towns' such as Junktown etc. In the wilderness you can encounter travelling tradesmen or evil creatures out to get you.The game is very intuitive allowing you to do most things with your mouse. The combat is particularly easy, aiming at an opponent gives you a pecentage chance of hitting. You can either shoot or try a different opponent. You often meet peole who will join your group, but be careful not to stand in front of them as they often manage to accidently hit you in combat!The graphics and sound are very atmospheric adding a little excitement to the game. Although the plot is weak, I found the game to be very enjoyable with some neat touches here and there. This game is definately a must for most rpgers out there.

content:
Posted: September 17, 2015
												It's the very first Fallout; nothing more or less than an absolute classic. The game will reward the players if they love the Fallout Lore & have previously played Fallout: New Vegas (Since Fallout: New Vegas is practically a sequel to Fallout 1 & 2). The game itself is very slow paced, and at times VERY frustrating, Anyone new to the original Fallout titles may not be thrilled at first, but once you start picking up on how the game plays, it's a lot of fun. Unfortunatley, you have to understand that this game is almost 20 years old. There are more glitches in this game than there are craters on the Moon! On top of that, you may experience a crash every now & then. Overall, the game is pretty solid for it's age. Worth a look!

content:
Posted: August 8, 2015
												The one that started it all.Together with the bugfixing/restoration mod Fallout Fixt, which has been maintained and updated to this day and I recommend it very much (http://www.nma-fallout.com/showthread.php?194562-Fallout-Fixt-0-81alpha-July-5th-2015), I have gathered around 80 hours of playtime in this game (the mod unfortunately uses its own shortcut to start the game and that's why my playtime isn't displayed on Steam). After the 1st attempt to start playing it half a year ago, I gave it a second shot while flying on the Fo4 hype. I've seen the story videos before already because I never expected that I'll play it. But that didn't stop me. All I can say that I was having a fricking blast while playing it, a bloody great and addictive game. Getting used to it takes a bit of time at the beginning, but don't let that to distract you. This starting guide is ideal for first time players and also has a picture of the keyboard shortcuts to save you some time: http://newfallout.com/fallout-1-quick-start-guide/If you get lost during the walkthrough, this one is perfect to get you out of trouble: http://strategywiki.org/wiki/FalloutAll I can say is that any true Fallout fan should check this game...either play it or just watch the story videos on Youtube.Highly recommended from me.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 7, 2015
												From what I've played (slightly more than my in- game time by a few hrs because I played on a friends' account too), this game is a masterpiece of 1997 that can run on even the slowest of toasters. The game itself is a turn- based role- playing game, which has its pros and cons:Pros:- It's a classic game, and looks it, but still is amazing fun.- Fans of other Fallout games will finally get references that you didn't get before. For example, you meet than man who ends up later on as the founder of the NCR, and the town he lived in. You'll meet Harold before he branched out. (Go on then, give me the thumbs down for that pun), the original Dogmeat etc.- It's hilarious on a 1e AD&D level. It's possible to play a character with a maxed out guns skill, and miss a man standing right in front of you with a pistol and drop the gun right in front of him.- Dogmeat is a boss. He will single- handedly destroy ANYTHING in your path short of a Deathclaw or Super Mutant. Give your human companions decent gear, and they'll do the same.- It feels awesome to get hold of the better stuff, like Power Armour.- Has a brilliant sense of humour. You'll see hilarious random encounters on rare occasions.- The amount of care put into this game is INCREDIBLE. Just give your character 3 Intelligence at creation, you'll see exactly what I mean.Cons:- One of the most unforgiving games I've ever played. (Word of advice, don't talk to Rhombus, he'll kind of kick you out of the BoS if you walk into his room). One false move, and it's all over. Need to reload the other save.- "Tell me abouts". You can ask a man in Shady sands to tell you a little about the place, and he'll say "Never heard of it". It really isn't worth using.- You're rushed from the start. The world is your oyster- once you get that water chip back to the vault.- Steep learning curve, and no tutorials. Watch a couple YouTube vids or look for guides online to learn how to properly play.I'd recommend it as an 8/10. Just make sure to tag the Small Guns skill at character creation (and use guns over any other weapon), and you'll be fine.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												To me, Fallout is THE definitive RPG, similar to Doom being THE definitive shooter. Although the world offers a lot of depth, it affects the player directly enough to inspire purpose. For example, it has more story compared to Icewind dale, but is not as long-winded as Baldur's Gate. Nevertheless, the writing is superb and combined with an amazing soundtrack it creates a memorable retro-futuristic experience. The game is also more open – there is a map, but it's up to you to discover if, when and where you will travel. Even though combat is turn-based, it is surprisingly packed with action. Just make double sure to turn combat speed all the way to maximum in options. Even today, one has to appreciate the animations when you blow a hole through an enemy's torso or cut him in half with a laser rifle.I think that since its release, I completed this game at least 50 times. So why do I still consider it worth playing after so many years, since I pretty much know its world like my own backyard? Despite all of this, there is still plenty of variety in the game. You see, the player has a great deal of control over how linear, open, short or long the playthrough is, even though you do not realize it at the beginning. So first, there are so many different approaches and play styles simply related to what kind of character you design and act as (commando, sniper, spy, librarian, doctor, pacifist, Hodor, etc.). Then there is the absolutely amazing diversity of how you deal with problems. When you complete it more than one time you will sometimes think: “Wow, I did not of this before!” Let me just point out that it is possible to complete Fallout 1 by leaving behind hundreds of corpses or by never killing anyone (I am not kidding). It all depends on how you observe, interpret and act upon the game world. And finally, there is our mistress random chance. Her effects are subtle and never in the game you get the feeling that regardless of your skill it all comes down to a coin toss (like in FTL, for example). But they are present enough for the game to be able to surprise you regardless of how well you know it. For example, in my many playthroughs only once I had such amazing luck that after leaving Vault 15 I was ambushed by a well armed party and after disposing of them I received a much better armor than is expected at that point in the game. Almost immediately after that I encountered a merchant party and decided on a whim to be an evil materialist. I put my above average gear to use and slaughtered them all. As I prepared my backpack full of goods to be sold later and thinking things can't get any better at this point, I received the Alien Blaster special encounter (never happened to me so early in the game). So before I even got to the Raiders or Junktown, I was already outfitted well enough to be a real threat to basically anyone in the game with the correct use of tactics. And on the other end – only once I had such bad luck that before reaching Vault 15, I was ambushed so severely that there was no way to ever win and I had to try very hard several times to even escape alive.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												Honestly, I didn't expect to enjoy the original fallout, but I was very happy to see my expectations blown through the roof.  Now I'm not saying that Fallout 1 is only better than bad or horrible, it is GENUINELY GREAT.  The core turn-based gameplay is highly addictive and does encourage players to not necessarily fight harder, but also to think smarter.  Fallout 1, unlike some other games, is not solely driven by brutally blowing off bad guy's limbs (however fun that always is), and it always adds some depth behind every enemy encounter.  Sure, methodically killing rats and radscorpions never quite requires any real mental strain, but I often found myself dreading gang attacks or other random encounters, as violence is the only real option in a RPG strongly based on player choice.  WARNING: Don't expect the gameplay to always seem fair, as the game loves to grant enemies with loads of critical strikes which often add to the player's annoyance.In addition to the combat, the exploration portion of the game is also excellent.  The gigantic wasteland offers many great random encounters, and a certain giddyness comes with finding and exploring a new town, Vault, or any other settlement.  Spoken dialogue with NPCs is scarce however, but the few pieces of spoken dialogue and face-to-face encounters with NPCs really color the scene.Don't expect too much from the graphics. Remember, if this game was a person, it would almost be reaching drinking age!  Sound effects are well produced if a little repetitive from time to time.The overarching main story and varying additional quests will keep a player well occupied for a long time, and with Fallout 4 approaching, the game provides a good excursion to the original West Coast Wasteland.  So do yourself a favor and pick up the classic RPG that started the franchise, either as a trip through memory lane or as a first time trip through the nuclear apocalypse.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
												So a couple of months ago with the imminent release of Fallout 4 looming a decided to go back and see what this franchise was all about. I figured it would be a good idea to start at # 1 in the series..... I was wrong. I'm sure that if I'd played this in the 90's it would have been acceptable, even good but I'm sorry this game by todays standards looks and plays terribly. The controls are beyond clunky and the learning curve is very steep. You will die a lot. A hell of a lot. It's a shame because the great Fallout concept is still there and you want to see what's around the corner but randomly searching a desert then coming across enemies that you are not yet equipped to defeat and dying isn't all that fun alas.I'm moving on to Fallout 2 to see if that scratches my itch. If you're like me and are new to the series and want to get into it maybe just go straight to Fallout 4 but rest assured you're better off without the original.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
												I must admit that I didn't fall in love with the original games, but rather, with the Bethesda-era ones. My first game in the series was Fallout 2 and while I LOVE older games like this, there was just something that didn't capture my attention like NV eventually did, which thankfully got me into the whole series.That being said, after playing countless hours of 3, NV, and 4, I decided to come back and have another go at completing the originals, going in order. I haven't quite finished this game's main quest, in fact I haven't really even come close, but I have to say that these games are far more enjoyable when you understand the game's universe and decide to force yourself to be patient with an unforgiving game. Typically, I don't like brutally tough games because I play games for enjoyment rather than overabundance of challenge, but once you get the hang of it, the challenge in this game goes hand-in-hand with the choice and depth.I will say that for a game of its age, it looks pretty good. However, my complaint is that because they went with the isometric approach, I find it harder to actually become immersed in the world itself. Instead, I find myself revisiting my childhood as I see images of 90s-era 3D in my head, trying to imagine what it would have looked like had they made it in first-person like Bethesda did with their games. I like isometric games, one of my favorites being the first two Rollercoaster Tycoon games, but for a semi-depressing, deep RPG with questions of morality, it feels lacking in the immersion factor.Where the graphics are lacking, the gameplay and story make up for it though. I have to say I despise the combat system mostly because you're locked into a single decision every round, but the turn-based system does allow for far more decisionmaking and strategy in combat which is nice. I can't begin to describe how many times I've died in the more recent games simply because the in-the-moment decisionmaking pressured me into pulling off a stupid move, so the turn-based system helps prevent that. I don't care much for the random encounters either, as they get annoying when you're trying to travel.The world itself is well-designed, despite the graphics being less immersive. The stylization gives a depressing, dark atmosphere of a ruined world, and there is something about that era of graphics/design that really hits you just right. The world isn't extremely open-world, but this isn't meant to be an open-world RPG. You use a fast travel type system between cities, settlements, regions and you're often interrupted by random encounters in the middle of nowhere. The larger cities/dungeons themselves tend to be split into several separate maps. There isn't a whole lot of variety in environment design but it doesn't need it. In general, the world captures you in a way you can't really describe with words, though not really by immersion factor.The story is entertaining, and it's fun to be able to basically carve your own path to your endgame objective, as RPGs are meant to be. The story begins simply, but then begins to expand until you realize it's a plot larger than you could have imagined. It involves choice in ridiculous amounts, not to mention it tries to reaffirm the series motto: "War... war never changes." by showing that despite destroying ourselves, humanity is still its selfish old self, yet we also have the capability of goodness and love.I apologize that this review was kind of scatterbrained, but I can't really do an appropriate review until I finish the game in its entirety like I have with the newer ones. Altogether, despite my complaints with this game and the original games in general, I do strongly recommend this game both for Fallout fans seeking nostalgia and for fans of traditional deep RPGs with a turn-based combat system. It's a load of fun, particularly once you get the hang of how it works.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												It's a good game, that's for sure. It really stands on its own as an innovation in rpgs. This is the great gand-pappy. The original progenitor of something great. It took a lot of innovation and imagination to make something like this happen, and we should be observant and respectful.There's a lot of limitations contained within; as is often the case with something new. Parts of the game don't feel fleshed out completely. As a result, I wouldn't classify Fallout as a complete experience per-se. No, the real reason to play Fallout is to experience the atmosphere. This game is full of ambient tracks and colorful dialogue. There's are also some "talking heads" you get to talk to, which further cement the experience. It lives and dies on its roleplay aspects. And even when things don't feel quite as complete as later fallout games, you have to give fallout some serious props for getting a lot of things right.Gameplay wise, there's not a lot to say. If you're serious enough, you could complete this game in 8 minutes. I guess that's where the weakness of Fallout comes from. Its limitations translates into a limited gameplay experience. And that's ok. Fallout is still a good game, and should be a must play for anyone who loves a good old-fashioned traditional rpg experience.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												I played this game many times back in the day. It's replay value is great because of all the different storylines you can take. Like all the fallout games afterwards, this one has multiple endings depending on the choices you make. The story is so well developed in this game you'll wonder why you haven't played this game sooner. When you start the game you'll be treated to with one of the most chilling, well-written introductions a game has ever been blessed with. Above all, the NPC interaction and voice acting are the best in any game to date. This game is possibly the best investment an RPG fan can presently make, and will prove entertaining for countless gaming hours. The game has excellent character generation and skill system, great story, and classy delivery. The compelling plot, and intuitive gameplay should deservedly broaden its appeal beyond the hard-core role-playing game audience. However, unlike the new fallout games, this is turn based which might turn some people off. If you are fan of the new Xcom, then you will be fan of this classic game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												One of the all-time classic RPGs which focus on a post-apocalytip setting and the people therein. You are a vault dweller, one of many who hid within deep underground vaults as nukes scorched the earth, sent on behalf of your community out into the world.The strength of the game lies in:- The overarching plot.- Great dialogue and characters.- Presentation of the setting and environment.- Character customization.However, as this is an old game, some features are a bit clunky for those of us more familiar with newer RPGs. You have to manually save and load the game, or set up the quicksave and quickload slot each time you start a game or have overwritten the slot. The environment expects you to engage it with the skills you have, such as using science on computer terminals and repair on machines, which may cause you to miss out on important clues. A very helpful keymap is shown when F1 is pressed to aid you.Overall, this is one of the classics of the genre which must be tried.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2016
												Great game. Refreshing change from modern gameplay. Something I found interesting is that fast travel is used extensively. Not the modern teleporting type, but your character moves across the map as an arrow when travelling between locations. Can be attacked along the way, cancelling the travel - likelehood of being attacked dependent kf skills. Also is how random encounters are experienced. Higher chance of specific encounters when moving across certain map tiles. Due to overhead view, exploring locations is quicker than modern fallouts, as you can see everything around you - needed for the rich environment. Highly recommend.

Posted: February 16, 2016
												If you are used to the endless dog-quests of Fallout 3, NV & 4; prepare to think. Prepare to prepare as an onslaught of possibly impossible enemies is placed before you. Get ready to scrounge, get ready to simply try and survive, with the vault’s survival weighing over you in an actual day-timer. 	The feeling of Fallout lingers. The world, more than in FPS sticks with you. A weighted lingering that haunts you, making one think of the world about, the world shattered beyond comprehension. An occasional far-off reminder, whispers that this is California. 	When you play this game, you feel like you are playing a legend. Seeing where it all started, and how far (or not) things have come. One thing I will tell you, this is no easy walk in the wasteland.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 30, 2015
												If you want to see where it all started, check out the first installment of one of the best game sagas in existence.Fallout: A Post Nuclear Role Playing Game features a pretty great story line, creative and compelling and before its time. Character customization even in this early installment still gives you a lot of control over your character and their capabilities, and plot lines altered by players' decision give the player a sense of ownership over the outcomes. Games like this spark the fire that become today's RPG gaming. Turn-based game play involves a little more forethought in strategy than fans of modern games are used to, you find less quick reaction is useful and more preparation and anticipation of combat needs will save you. It is important to remember that 1997 is before the time of auto-save.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 15, 2015
												WOWThis game is amazing. I have bought a million copies of this: the big box when it was first released, countless jewel case releases, got it for free (?) on GOG when they were just about to lose the rights to distribute the FO series, and finally on Steam as part of a sale a year ago or so.Each time I tried to get into this game, the interface turned me off. Now, I grew up playing RPGs on C64 so you could say I have some tolerance for cumbersome interfaces. However, FO's interface defeated me at every turn. As much as I like the game, the interface is still annoying, with my three most hated things being:- Inventory UI: the fact that each item is a giant picture and 90% of the screen is wasted makes managing inventory a colossal pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ Toward the end of the game I was sporting enhanced power armor on a low STR character, so I had to manage inventory a lot. I seriously spent an hour toward the end just cleaning everything up, selling stuff I don't need (999 bottle caps at a time...), and shuffling (using pickpocket... how ridiculous is this) inventory between my companions, only to just ditch them for the last two segments of the game- Conversation UI: a measly few lines of text, with 90% of the screen being taken up by the UI. I am not complaining about the space for the animated faces (very useful to gauge reactions), but all the♥♥♥♥♥♥on the sides etc. This is true also for the TINY window on the bottom of the screen listing game information. There were cases where normal events in the game would overload that tiny display with text and I would have to go scroll through it all to read it. Why does a GIANT picture of your equipped weapon/item take us so much space on the main game screen? Makes no sense.- Companion interaction: total nightmare. Even if you spec a combat monster, you will need companions to get you through much of the early game. Outside of battle they are not only useless, but hinder your every move. Walking into small rooms is a nightmare because they will inevitably stand in the doorway... and just stand there. You can "pickpocket" (!!!) them to give them better weapons, but they are stuck with ♥♥♥♥♥♥ armor the entire game. Even using them as pack mules is a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ During the last 20% of the game I just dismissed them all, since they would all be killed instantly by mutant patrol miniguns.OKWith that all out of the way, Fallout is still one of the greatest if not the greatest RPG ever made. The sheer number of ways to complete this game, all the sidequests, the fact that you will never see everything in a single game... wow. Playing through to the end for the first time, I felt like, no matter what I did, the game was one step ahead of me. You think of some way to tackle an objective, and Fallout just goes, haha yeah I knew you'd do that and gives you a kickass weapon anyway.I started out with a high INT/speech character with small guns tagged, so a lot of early stuff was talking my way through situations. Once I got a sniper rifle, I basically turned into a combat beast and I plowed through the last quarter of the game in power armor, basically untouchable. I have never played a game that gives you so much freedom. I wonder if there is a character build that is literally impossible to finish the game with.On top of all this is an amazing presentation. It still looks great today (especially the backgrounds), and the soundtrack is incredibly moody. It took me 20 hours start to finish, not including time spent dying/reloading, and I savored every minute.My recommendations for playing:- First of all, save often and have an open mind.  Have fun with the game, it is a playground of imagination.- I suggest keeping the resolution at 640x480, which the game was designed to be run at.  Higher resolutions do not do the art justice.- Turn fog of war on so that uneplored parts of maps are blacked out.  Might be a personal preference, but this made me want to explore each map even more, and felt more realistic than being able to see everything the minute you walk on to a new map.- Move the pathfinding slider all the way to the max.  You will have to go back and forth over several maps over and over, and the pathfinding restrictions in the vanilla game are annoying.  Max it out so you can just click on the exit and have your characters navigate to them themselves.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 5, 2015
												What can be said about this classic masterpiece, that hasn't been said already? if you never played Fallout, you might be wondering if "it is really that good, or it is just nostalgia". The short answer is yes, it is incredibly good. It is easily one of the best 5 RPGs ever released.I'll start with the aspects of the game that may not be that good. Inventory management is cumbersome, as you can only view a few items at the same time and have to scroll up and down constantly. Overall the UI is not as "comfortable" to use as modern UIs. Also, the enemy AI is a bit primitive (not that newer games are any better, actually...) and you'll also find that some character development options are obvious "traps" that may make you restart the game. for instance, there's certain skills that you can raise easily spending money in-game; if you don't know that and spend your valuable points there, you'll seriously handicap yourself. Same with some weapon skill choices. Finally, companions are rather weak, since you can't equip them nor they seem to progress nor follow any orders; they are fragile and suicidal, so in the endgame you're better off without them. Now that the "not perfect" things are out of the way, let's get to the meaty part.The setting and the whole idea about Fallout is brilliant, and has been executed perfectly, much better depicted and detailed than in the new Bethesda sequels. Dialogues are short yet well-written, the layout and pacing of the story makes sense, and the atmosphere when you explore places like Vault 15 or The Glow absolutely delivers. The game can feel oppresive and dark when it wants to, yet there is plenty of humor that even breaks the "fourth wall" sometimes, and it has been added with good taste, so it doesn't erode the game's apocalyptic atmosphere.Quests in this game put to shame most of the quest writers in this generation. So many different ways to solve them! and no, I don't mean the trivial meaningless choices for one reward or another you see in Skyrim; I mean that you can solve almost all the situations without violence, and you can make choices that really alter the world. There's a "dumb way", a "talky way", "sneaky way" to solve each problem, to a degree like no other RPG I can think of. This variety of choice is the essence of RPGs, what really makes you feel like you are "playing a role" in a unique way, different from what other players did. One of the reasons Fallout is so immersive is because it really brings on the table the element of survival. Unlike in most RPGs, where you quickly escalate the curve of power and become invulnerable, you can be easily killed in Fallout, always. Friendly fire is always a big risk, and even in the end game, and having good weapons and armor, you can get shot down rather quickly if your strategy is bad. Which encourages thinking, and caring. Survival becomes the main focus in the game, which is quite amazing. The moment you begin feeling "safe" in a setting like this, you can say that it has failed to deliver.Yet, once you understand the tactical elements in the game, it is not that hard. Difficulty is very well gauged in my opinion, punishing you when you are reckless or pick the wrong fights, yet allowing you to gain advantage when you do things right and choose the right tools for each job. As it should be.There's many more aspects I could talk about, I suppose. Sound and music are good, art is sometimes outstanding, sometimes adequate. Overland map allows to travel in a non-cumbersome way, without losing the feeling of "exploration". And the details make obvious this game was made with love and patience. Little things like weapon descriptions, or small humorous references in dialogues, or some of the random encounters. Classy. Timeless. 10/10. Must play if you love the genre.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 26, 2015
												Today, a conversation about the pros and cons of Fallout 4 lead to a co-worker getting nostalgic for the original Interplay Fallouts, with supposedly more in-depth interactions with NPCs, where decisions regarding finite character builds hold more weight, where targeted shots (now V.A.T.S.) actually matter, and where power armour is something to work towards.When Fallout was new my only interaction with it was watching over the shoulder of a friend as they slid items in and out of equipment slots and frantically clicked on a green diagram of giant scorpion parts.Two years ago I thought I'd try it for myself but was quite shocked to realize I'd just bought a game from Steam that would not run as-is. After venturing into unofficial patches and the realm of "fixt", I got so far as a green triangle on a world map labeled "unknown" just outside Shady Sands. And no matter what I tweaked regarding installed patches; trying to enter Shady Sands would cause the game to fail without fail.I gave up and let it collect dust.Until today. Thanks to my co-worker reminiscing on the things Fallout got right the first time, I decided to give it another go. I searched for any new news in getting the old game to run but just ended up feeling like a super-mutant wandering through "No Mutants Allowed." But while thinking up my negative review I did the one thing I hadn't done: deleted the patched-and-tweaked-game, then downloaded, reinstalled and ran it again, completely vanilla.And it works. No colour issues. No black screens. How? Why? I don't care. I'm looking forward to finally... fiiiinally talking to these peasants in this boring town of Shady Sands, then maybe punching some radscorpions this guy Seth told me about... and whatever else the game has in store of course!So if others were running up against the same problems and beginning to go insane: here's hoping I haven't simply fallen into some anomalous group of people for whom the game "just works" and that it works for you too!

content:
Posted: May 19, 2015
												Fallout is deserving of the title 'classic'. Some people struggle with the graphics these days but this has absolutely no bearing on how good this game is. The writing and tactical turn based combat work just as well today as they did two decades ago. It is a strong story driven RPG with quite a lot of adult/dark humour. It also doesn't really hold your hand and there are some people/creatures you don't want to mess with. Save often and don't start what you can't finish.Be sure to download the various fan made mods that include restored content and bug fixes to maximize your enjoyment.8/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												Fallout will please roleplaying fans everywhere. Set in a post apocalyptic world, Fallout starts out with you (the hero) leaving the safety of your underground village to search for a water purifier which is essential for the continued survival of your village.The outer world has a similar feeling to the 'MAD MAX' movies without the cars. Through many towns you interact with seperate factions and gangs, often invoving your self in quests, or trying to avoid being killed!You can design your own character or use a predesigned character. You have several statistics which combined with some 'characteristics' give you a list of percentile abilities (e.g. small gun 65% - meaning you have a 65% chance of hitting an enemy in normal conditions!).The world is set out in several sections. Based on a vast grid, you have many wilderness boxes and several 'towns' such as Junktown etc. In the wilderness you can encounter travelling tradesmen or evil creatures out to get you.The game is very intuitive allowing you to do most things with your mouse. The combat is particularly easy, aiming at an opponent gives you a pecentage chance of hitting. You can either shoot or try a different opponent. You often meet peole who will join your group, but be careful not to stand in front of them as they often manage to accidently hit you in combat!The graphics and sound are very atmospheric adding a little excitement to the game. Although the plot is weak, I found the game to be very enjoyable with some neat touches here and there. This game is definately a must for most rpgers out there.

												I could not tell you about my love for  the first fallout game, but I shall try. Fallout is the story of the vault dweller......no duh. He is sent out to look for a water chip because the one in his vault has died. It is a race against time to save your vault and meet some rather odd people along the way.The atmosphere for this game is great. It is rather dark and sometimes rather depressing, however, it has some of the best dark humor I have seen in a game to date. The only problem I have with this game is that it is slightly unforgiving and will take a while to understand what you need to do and where you need to go. There is also a time limit at the start of the game, but it goes away after you main goal is done (Well, it gives you 13 in game years, which is more then enough time to finish all the side quest and more).I give Fallout a nice 4/5  for being a great game that holds up rather well for today's standards.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 30, 2015
												The past several years haven't exactly been kind to role-playing game fans. Very few role-playing games have been released since 1993, and those that have made it to retail shelves have largely been unsuccessful at combining playability and originality with the complexity that role-playing game fans love. The release of Blizzard Entertainment's action/role-playing game hybrid Diablo in early 1997 only increased role-playing gamers' anticipation for an equally playable game in a more elaborate, detailed world. After a four-year drought, the wait is over. Fallout is one of the best role-playing games to be released in several years and it succeeds in entertaining gamers by providing a fresh and compelling storyline, good graphics and sound, and attention to those little details that can transform a good game into a great one.Fallout is an unofficial sequel to 1987's Wasteland, one of the most popular role-playing games of all time. While the overwhelming majority of computer role-playing games are set in some pseudo-medieval, Tolkien/AD&D-inspired world of orcs and battleaxes, Fallout is set in the future, several years after an exchange of nuclear weapons has devastated most of the world. Inhabitants who survived did so largely by sheltering themselves in giant underground vaults. Your character's life has been spent entirely within one such vault. A broken chip for your vault's water recycler forces your character to leave the relative safety of the vault to search for a replacement chip aboveground in the wasteland, where you'll encounter struggling communities of survivors, Road Warrior-esque gangs, human mutants, and even stranger creatures. Hardly a typical setting for a role-playing game, but the originality of the setting is one of the strengths of Fallout. In Fallout, rather than trudging through yet another dreary dungeon, in search of ye olde magic artifact to expel demon horde #782, your character will explore the haunting remnants of our own civilization and attempt to unravel the mysterious forces at work in postapocalyptic Southern California. The old 90210 neighborhood has changed, gang violence is rampant, two-headed cows roam Rodeo, and the new fashion accessory is a rocket launcher. And if the guns of the locals don't get you, the radiation might. Brandon, Kelly, why are you glowing like that?

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												Honestly, I didn't expect to enjoy the original fallout, but I was very happy to see my expectations blown through the roof.  Now I'm not saying that Fallout 1 is only better than bad or horrible, it is GENUINELY GREAT.  The core turn-based gameplay is highly addictive and does encourage players to not necessarily fight harder, but also to think smarter.  Fallout 1, unlike some other games, is not solely driven by brutally blowing off bad guy's limbs (however fun that always is), and it always adds some depth behind every enemy encounter.  Sure, methodically killing rats and radscorpions never quite requires any real mental strain, but I often found myself dreading gang attacks or other random encounters, as violence is the only real option in a RPG strongly based on player choice.  WARNING: Don't expect the gameplay to always seem fair, as the game loves to grant enemies with loads of critical strikes which often add to the player's annoyance.In addition to the combat, the exploration portion of the game is also excellent.  The gigantic wasteland offers many great random encounters, and a certain giddyness comes with finding and exploring a new town, Vault, or any other settlement.  Spoken dialogue with NPCs is scarce however, but the few pieces of spoken dialogue and face-to-face encounters with NPCs really color the scene.Don't expect too much from the graphics. Remember, if this game was a person, it would almost be reaching drinking age!  Sound effects are well produced if a little repetitive from time to time.The overarching main story and varying additional quests will keep a player well occupied for a long time, and with Fallout 4 approaching, the game provides a good excursion to the original West Coast Wasteland.  So do yourself a favor and pick up the classic RPG that started the franchise, either as a trip through memory lane or as a first time trip through the nuclear apocalypse.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 29, 2012
												This is one of my all-time favorite games, if not the number one slot.  It's one of my earliest memories of enjoying the hell out of a game and really comprehending how to play a game efficiently rather than just arbitrarily flailing at the controls as I often would as a child.   Fallout has an amazing setting, and a wonderful sense of humor.  A world where America never really left that era of 50's idealism, and kept that attidude and commerical style all the way through to World War 3, which saw the destruction of nearly all of the civilized world.  Many people sought shelter from the Nuclear War in underground, impenetrable vaults where they thought they would be safe until the planet recovered.  As a man/woman who must venture out into the wasteland for the sake of their vault's survival, and brave a world warped by war and fire, patrolled by freakish mutants and roving gangs of bandits.  Amazing RPG. Memorable conversations, events and characters.Play this game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 7, 2015
												One of those Golden Classics, the Combat can be a bit slow, you might be a bit used to Autosave and forget to save now and then, but definatly worth it.Agility and Intelligence is quite important in the two first fallout game as Action Point and Skill Points are your bread and butter. There are also possible to pick up books to acquire skills to a relative high level, and in this game you can even buy them from a store in the Hub. I suggest Saving often, especially before you start quests and the like because the game run on its own time table once you take a quest, and the bad guys might kill the good guy because you used to long. Which is one of the things I used to love about this game.Getting a Power Armor really makes things easier as it boost your strength with 2 so you never really need more than 8 in strength as 10 is maximum, Ranged Fighting is definatly the way to go so I really suggest stacking agility, perception and intelligence above the other stats (or cheat all the stats to 10 in everything :D) Anyhow the story is amazing, the music gives me goose bumps, and blasting muties to high heaven with a rocket launcher or saw em in half with my lazer gatling gun or Turbo-charged Plasma Rifle..... Worth every god damn penny.I think that Bethesda never did Fallout 1 or 2 any justice, it was like Fallout Tactics was placed in 3D, without the option for multiple party members.  I know I am a Bioware Fanboy, but I think they would have done a 1000 times better job with the game series than Bethesda ever could hope to come up with. But this isnt about those awful games that came after these gems... Fallout 1 and 2 are worth it.

												A classic, plain and simple. Its a merciless game but, intensely addicting. Vastly different play style than from Fallout 3 and New Vegas, its a third person view turn based combat, there are plenty of fights you'll encounter that require a good deal of planning. The storyline is shorter compaired to the other games but eacht ime you play the experience is completely different based on your SPECIAL stats. The only downside is this has trouble running on current machines, I tracked down some patches that fix it but still run into some issues with stability. This of course is to be expected from an older game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 30, 2015
												If you want to see where it all started, check out the first installment of one of the best game sagas in existence.Fallout: A Post Nuclear Role Playing Game features a pretty great story line, creative and compelling and before its time. Character customization even in this early installment still gives you a lot of control over your character and their capabilities, and plot lines altered by players' decision give the player a sense of ownership over the outcomes. Games like this spark the fire that become today's RPG gaming. Turn-based game play involves a little more forethought in strategy than fans of modern games are used to, you find less quick reaction is useful and more preparation and anticipation of combat needs will save you. It is important to remember that 1997 is before the time of auto-save.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												Fallout is quite an experience. Like most games, Fallout has its quarks and times when you get a little frustrated at a small detail or lack there of. However, for myself, when I began to play Fallout I was enthrolled with the world in which I was to explore. Being a vet of Fallout 3 and New Vegas I wasn't sure how I would feel about a tactical turn based combat system. I was pleasantly surprised to find out how much it felt like I was playing a tabletop RPG. All in all, Fallout is a game I will always remember fondly with its exciting quest plots and interesting characters and situations. But it's downsides were slightly taxing, I would say it is worth $10 but if you get it on sale it is absolutly worth the time and investment.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 9, 2014
												I was late to get into the Fallout games but I have finally dug in and I enjoy the world and the progression in this game a lot. I am normally averse to turn-based type games but the fallout action points system to me seems very well integrated and keeps things fresh and intersting. The character creation is fairly robust, (aside from the inability to really change the character model in meaningful ways) and its great that the game really gives a breadth of options to get past its obstacles. The Fallout universe is by far the most interesting post-apocalyptic world I've been exposed to. It feels like a living, breathing, and extraordinary world with individuals struggling to survive in the wasteland. Leveling up and succeeding at tasks feels very rewarding. The perk system allows a lot of room to make a unique experience with each character and lets you really take advantage of what you value in your playstyle. Its definitely worth being considered a classic.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
												Fallout is a really great game once you get into it.  At first, the game can be difficult to get into because it is so much different than Fallout 3 and Fallout: New Vegas.  If you don't build your character correctly like I did on my first character, you may not enjoy the game very much (I know I didn't).  Once I looked up a guide on how to build a good character and then started a new character following the guide, Fallout became much more enjoyable because I was actually able to kill things more powerful than Radscorpians and Mole Rats.I would also recommend looking up a quest list for each area in the game.  This way, you know what characters to talk to to start each quest.  After that, solve the quests on your own, but use the guides to at least start them.  On my first character I didn't do this and I found myself bored very quickly because I wasn't able to find anyone that would give me a quest.Overall, Fallout is a great game.  It is a little dated and the combat system will take some getting used to, but the story is great.  Fallout will give some great backstory for players that have played Fallout 3 and Fallout: New Vegas.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
												[Note: The game time logged on Steam does not reflect the time I spent playing Fallout to date. I bought it back in 1997 on CD-ROM and have owned a couple of other bundles which included it since, and have completed Fallout at least a dozen of times since first release.]This was the very first of the Fallout games, and it is still in my all-time-favorite games list today. With added community enhancements, hi-res patches and unofficial updates, this game is still fun, unique to play, and more complex than it was on its release date; and the best part is, even a low-powered netbook can run this just fine. The post-apocalyptic world is diverse, the humor is brilliant to say the least, and this game is just worth being played just for the random encounters alone.The character creation is fun, you get a wide array of cool weapons (such a modified shotgun based pistol!), and even after a number of playthroughs, there are still new items to discover. If you love RPGs, if you love a post-apocalyptic sci-fi setting, and if you have an affinity for the Fallout universe (even if you started with Fallout 3), then you should certainly give this a try, even if it might look a little dated. The graphics, as they are, in fact help the atmosphere. I probably completed this game over a dozen times.Given the fact that Fallout is from 1997, a time in which video games were not quite established yet as a socially accepted entertainment form, the voice acting provided by actors like Ron Perlman, Michael Dorn and Dwight Schultz is also superb! If you don't like this game, you were born a generation too late and I feel sorry for you!

content:
Posted: October 17, 2015
												For those of us who cut our teeth on later installments of the series, Fallout may seem a bit unpolished. However, there is everything to love in and about the debut title of the series. Targeting your enemies squishy bits with bullets, lasers, or melee strikes is just as much fun as it ever was. As always you're free to sneak around, pick locks, and steal loot to line your pockets with bottlecaps. Even though there may be less character development in Fallout than in later installments, it's worth exploring the humble beginings of the factions and storylines that have been developed throughout the series.If it existed in a vacuum I might say that $10.00 is too steep, and if one had no connection or attraction to the series at large I would likely advise against starting with Fallout. However, for those of you who already love one or more Fallout games do yourself a favor and go back in time to where it all began.

number of helpful: No ratings yet1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 15, 2015
												This game is a classic that laid the foundation for the popular Fallout games that followed. However returning to this game years later and leaving my nostalgia glasses on my bed stand I found this game to still be enjoyable, funny dialogue, rewarding gameplay, dynamic-ish character development (even if it is just gun hoping until you eventually find a laser weapon and start maxing energy weapons).However this game is certainly dated, with a lot of issues with character controls, targetting, and map navigation. Also the ambiguity factor is set at a 10, which is fine for games like Dark Souls where there's really only so many places you can go, in this you'll run your cursor across the screen playing "find the named NPC" and hope they can feed you the next bread crum so you can figure out why you are in the place you're in.Furthermore this game, being a product of the early DnD era suffers from what I like to call the "Lol get crit ♥♥♥♥♥♥" syndrome. Where fully encassed in power armor some guy will punch you for 0 three times in a row, then on the fourth punch get lucky enough to touch Zeus' beard with that 20 and crit you for anywhere from 30-70 damage. Makes constant saving and loading essentially a necessiry as you play post apocalyptic craps. Though I could write an entire thesis about why I dislike crit mechanics like these, it basically boils down to your crits of this magnitude never feeling rewarding, as it feels like the win was just given to you, while the enemy crits of this magnitude feel cheap and unfair leaving the player feeling like there was nothing they could do they simply lost this spin on the slot machine.This game may have been a 9/10 then, but probably only like a 6 or maybe 7 now. Game aged about as well as a gallon of milk left out in the hot SoCal sun.Overall Rating: 6.5/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 5, 2015
												What can be said about this classic masterpiece, that hasn't been said already? if you never played Fallout, you might be wondering if "it is really that good, or it is just nostalgia". The short answer is yes, it is incredibly good. It is easily one of the best 5 RPGs ever released.I'll start with the aspects of the game that may not be that good. Inventory management is cumbersome, as you can only view a few items at the same time and have to scroll up and down constantly. Overall the UI is not as "comfortable" to use as modern UIs. Also, the enemy AI is a bit primitive (not that newer games are any better, actually...) and you'll also find that some character development options are obvious "traps" that may make you restart the game. for instance, there's certain skills that you can raise easily spending money in-game; if you don't know that and spend your valuable points there, you'll seriously handicap yourself. Same with some weapon skill choices. Finally, companions are rather weak, since you can't equip them nor they seem to progress nor follow any orders; they are fragile and suicidal, so in the endgame you're better off without them. Now that the "not perfect" things are out of the way, let's get to the meaty part.The setting and the whole idea about Fallout is brilliant, and has been executed perfectly, much better depicted and detailed than in the new Bethesda sequels. Dialogues are short yet well-written, the layout and pacing of the story makes sense, and the atmosphere when you explore places like Vault 15 or The Glow absolutely delivers. The game can feel oppresive and dark when it wants to, yet there is plenty of humor that even breaks the "fourth wall" sometimes, and it has been added with good taste, so it doesn't erode the game's apocalyptic atmosphere.Quests in this game put to shame most of the quest writers in this generation. So many different ways to solve them! and no, I don't mean the trivial meaningless choices for one reward or another you see in Skyrim; I mean that you can solve almost all the situations without violence, and you can make choices that really alter the world. There's a "dumb way", a "talky way", "sneaky way" to solve each problem, to a degree like no other RPG I can think of. This variety of choice is the essence of RPGs, what really makes you feel like you are "playing a role" in a unique way, different from what other players did. One of the reasons Fallout is so immersive is because it really brings on the table the element of survival. Unlike in most RPGs, where you quickly escalate the curve of power and become invulnerable, you can be easily killed in Fallout, always. Friendly fire is always a big risk, and even in the end game, and having good weapons and armor, you can get shot down rather quickly if your strategy is bad. Which encourages thinking, and caring. Survival becomes the main focus in the game, which is quite amazing. The moment you begin feeling "safe" in a setting like this, you can say that it has failed to deliver.Yet, once you understand the tactical elements in the game, it is not that hard. Difficulty is very well gauged in my opinion, punishing you when you are reckless or pick the wrong fights, yet allowing you to gain advantage when you do things right and choose the right tools for each job. As it should be.There's many more aspects I could talk about, I suppose. Sound and music are good, art is sometimes outstanding, sometimes adequate. Overland map allows to travel in a non-cumbersome way, without losing the feeling of "exploration". And the details make obvious this game was made with love and patience. Little things like weapon descriptions, or small humorous references in dialogues, or some of the random encounters. Classy. Timeless. 10/10. Must play if you love the genre.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 8, 2015
												I completely missed the older installments of Fallout like many fans; I didn't pick up the series until Fallout 3 and had little knowledge of the predecessors. The gameplay is vastly different, but I was pleasantly surprised and love how the theme and culture of the game really did ring through the series. I was in awe about how great the atmosphere of this game is; the music, brutality, twists, and the little tidbits that make it a great RPG. Granted, it's from 1997 so the expansive of the game was obviously limited by capabilities at the time.  Despite of that however... this game can get you addicted and playing for many hours! Leaving you begging for more and you understand why it's a series. I highly recommend this game if you're a fan of Fallout theme; post-apocalypse, gritty realities, gory outcomes, and a moral compass thrown out the window. You'll fall in love with the towns, people, missions, and the outcomes that directly correlate to what you do. The action in this game is oriented toward classic RPGs; it is turn/dice roll statistics dependent. So you won't be running around... but you'll question your sanity when you smile every time an enemy's torso blows in half from a critical hit. You'll get 20+ hours of gameplay from this game if you play the main storyline and do the essential/big missions. I imagine there's much more to the game that I missed during my playthrough. Buy it. Enjoy it. And smile knowing there's sequels waiting for you.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												Talk about nostalgia. Brings me back to the age of 12. This is one of the all-time greatest games ever made. It changed roleplaying games forever, and birthed a post-apocolyptic sub-genre that still thrives today. The character creation system leaves the door open for multiple playthroughs, and allows you to feel more in touch with the character. Talk about pure roleplaying. Do you want your guy to be a scientist? A born-leader and hero? How about the dumbest man on the earth, but he's great with a sledgehammer and minigun? There are so many options. Playing with an intelligence of 1 will just make you laugh. You can always come back to this game for a good time. Another great thing to keep in mind, is that this will run on about ANY Windows machine. You can put it on your laptop for the go for a great travel game. And with the addition of Fallout FIXT, the game runs phenominal at 1080p resolution, and the community went ahead and fixed some of the issues plaguing the game since development halted years ago. Actually, Fallout FIXT was just updated on December 23, 2013! Let's hope that the classic Fallout titles return to Steam soon, it was sad to see them go!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 23, 2014
												War... War never changes.A concept that has driven a younger self to delve into the depths of human history and indulge in the ages of humanities stife. Fallout and its proceeding series has taken a Post- Nuclear apocalyptic outcome of humanity, peeking subsequently in the attitude, culture and design of 1950's United States of America...  on October 23, 2077 a final Nuclear showdown between the powerhouses of the world finally push the resource crippled Earth to its limits.The aftermath that ensued is what caries the Fallout series... 2161... 84 years after the grand conclusion to Man's pinacle.Unfotunately, the scarred earth was not left without it's demons looming. Pulling humanity ever downward or to one binding will or another.This did not mean all was lost though... Emergent groups; once sealed away long ago before the world went silent still had a chance to re-inherit a land all but forsaken by it's previous masters. The time had come for the those fortunate enough to hide away in sealed underground fortresses known as Vaults. These Vault Dwellers experienced a different form of life... Far from the raptured barren lands of the nuclear wasteland that was now the Americas.Fallout will take you through the Western United States of America, your mission... Save the Vault, your objectives, retrieve a Water-purification chip  and return with any details of the land.With the goal established you are pushed onto a desert frontier, far from the lush lands that once beheld the view.The game plays from a Top-down view of your characters, combat revolves around Action Points and maybe a bit of luck ;) to resolve any experience. Weapons range from rocks, spears and knives... To sub-machine guns, rifles and shotguns... Chainguns and rockets all the way up to the sci-fi laser and plasma weaponry in similar previous fashions.The Vault Dwellers or later to be known to most as The Wanderer... journey is one that always kept smirk of satisfaction on my face. The stories created here are later on exemplified in later games from the series.TL;DR: A game that was likely overlooked if you're in your early 20's and younger. Take the time, see how the story began and enjoy some good old fashion hexa-based combat.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												My Fallout experiences and what I thought of Fallout: A Post Nuclear Role Playing GameMy introduction to the Fallout franchise was through a friend of my elder brothers. Before going out, he peered his head into my room and left an Xbox 360 copy of Fallout 3 on my table for me to borrow. I was addicted. The start of the summer of 09' was spent wondering the DC ruins and soaking up everything that that insane game had to offer. A year later in 2010, New Vegas had came out. I ravenously guzzled it down within a month and was still hungry for more. For a massive history-buff like me, and all though it's set in the 2100's, the Fallout series offered a unique experience and had me totally engrossed in it's seemingly endless codex-like information and lore.So, some time later it is payday December 2013. By now I am on Steam (albeit still a noob) and I am searching the store. I get home from a freezing night of Christmas shopping with the girlfriend, and I notice the 'Fallout Bundle' going for around £3. Was this real?As soon as Fallout 1 had Installed I jumped on in.It took a while to get used to the old turn taking system, but you have to be open minded. Playing game series backwards in age is going to be off putting so you have to try and enjoy it for what it is. Saying this though, I got bored (Guilty as charged) and didn't play it for about half a year. As much as it pains me to say this, I just lost my will to play it entirely from sheer boredom.Into the not-so-distant future and the Fallout crave had started to come back. I reinstalled F:aPNRPG and jumped on into a new game. This time round, I curbed my ego and instead of playing Fallout 1 like I played Fallout 3 and NV, I decided to take a completely different approach.I forced myself to remember, this game was made when I was fifteen months old. Times were different back then. So I dumped myself in the desk chair, grabbed a tall drink of cola and walked out into the Vault 13 Caves.I didn't look back, and what a game it was. A solid 10/10. A beautifully minimalist/simple and believable plot too. Try it for yourself. If you are approaching this game from the future like I did, then be open minded. Only play it when you crave to. Otherwise you'll get bored and this gem will be missed out on. Next up, Fallout 2.

												Fallout, the first game in one of my favorite series of all time.  This game is awesome.  The pacing is great and isn't as difficult as the second one.  It works super well on any pc which is awesome.  The game's combat and exploration are its trademarks.  You can loot, kill, and do just about anything.  It is alot more forgiving than Fallout 2 but it isn't as long.  The story itself is unique and well paced.  I never felt while I was playing the game was taking too long.  I liked how you can find all the cool easter eggs that most companies don't ever put in their games now.  Get this game and it is on sale plenty of times so get it during one of the many sales steam does.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 1, 2014
												   I was first intorduced to the Fallout series when I played Fallout 3, which my friend highly recommended. He had been trying for weeks to get me to play, I finally gave in a decided to try it and I LOVED IT! I went on a Fallout binge, often playing for 10 or more hours per day. Then I finished the game and moved on to New Vegas.   Recently I decided I wanted to go back to the beginning and play the earlier games. I wasn't expecting very much, especially since it was made in 1997; but when I first started it I felt like it was a waste of money(even though I bought the bundle while it was on sale). After getting my butt kicked by Radscorpions and not knowing how to get better equipment I was about to give up, then I started goofing around and found out what I wanted to know.   So far I haven't progressed ver far in the main questline, but I have developed a new found respect for the original, in my opinion being better than the newer ones. The areas are quite large, the music is addicting,and the combat system is not as bad I though it to be.    My biggest challenge when I started playing was adjusting to the combat system. Since I started Fallout playing Fallout 3 it took some time to get used to the combat system in this game. After I got past that I started to love this game.   I highly recommend this game to any fan of Fallout

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 23, 2014
												War... War never changes.A concept that has driven a younger self to delve into the depths of human history and indulge in the ages of humanities stife. Fallout and its proceeding series has taken a Post- Nuclear apocalyptic outcome of humanity, peeking subsequently in the attitude, culture and design of 1950's United States of America...  on October 23, 2077 a final Nuclear showdown between the powerhouses of the world finally push the resource crippled Earth to its limits.The aftermath that ensued is what caries the Fallout series... 2161... 84 years after the grand conclusion to Man's pinacle.Unfotunately, the scarred earth was not left without it's demons looming. Pulling humanity ever downward or to one binding will or another.This did not mean all was lost though... Emergent groups; once sealed away long ago before the world went silent still had a chance to re-inherit a land all but forsaken by it's previous masters. The time had come for the those fortunate enough to hide away in sealed underground fortresses known as Vaults. These Vault Dwellers experienced a different form of life... Far from the raptured barren lands of the nuclear wasteland that was now the Americas.Fallout will take you through the Western United States of America, your mission... Save the Vault, your objectives, retrieve a Water-purification chip  and return with any details of the land.With the goal established you are pushed onto a desert frontier, far from the lush lands that once beheld the view.The game plays from a Top-down view of your characters, combat revolves around Action Points and maybe a bit of luck ;) to resolve any experience. Weapons range from rocks, spears and knives... To sub-machine guns, rifles and shotguns... Chainguns and rockets all the way up to the sci-fi laser and plasma weaponry in similar previous fashions.The Vault Dwellers or later to be known to most as The Wanderer... journey is one that always kept smirk of satisfaction on my face. The stories created here are later on exemplified in later games from the series.TL;DR: A game that was likely overlooked if you're in your early 20's and younger. Take the time, see how the story began and enjoy some good old fashion hexa-based combat.
