content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												If you haven't played Fallout 3 already, you're missing out. So not playing this might as well be the same thing. A top down mix of real time combat and turn based, Fallout will imerse you into the game GREATLY. I mean seriously, you can right click and hover your mouse cursor over anything and you get a detailed discription of it, then you can even left click to get an even MORE detailed description of it. The music is usually dark in most cases, kinda makes you feel like when the npcs' say, "It's dangerous there!" You feel like it's actually dangerous there. And speaking of danger, THIS GAME IS DIFFACULT. Half the time you die you don't even know the reason! Moving on to weapons and armor. New weapons and armor are quite rare, so actually finding a new weapon makes you feel great for finding it. I personally love this game, but it requires a lot of time, a lot of saving and a lot of imersing yourself into it, kinda making yourself feel like you are actually you in the game. I give it a 9/10. (Also there are a TON of easter eggs in the game that give you a fun challenge to do if you're bored; which you won't be with this game :D )

content:
Posted: November 8, 2016
												A surprisingly mature, well-written RPG that stands the test of time well. Though the controls, combat, and interaction may feel dated at first, once the player is immersed into the rich world of Fallout it is easy to look past such minor annoyances. There are some arcane solutions to quests, but due to the open-endedness of the game this is hardly an issue, as there are plenty of other paths to take if one becomes sealed off. The game is intelligently crafted so that each new playthrough can feel fresh (despite this being a rather linear game in comparison to newer entries), and the story is both well-paced and adaptive to the player's actions. This, when compared to, for example, Fallout 3, contains not only a great deal more player agency, but also an ending that changes and carefully describes the player's impact on the game's world. I was found reflecting on my earlier actions when the final cinematic rolled for the first time, questioning just how much of the plot's aftermath was directly influenced by my choices.If you are interested in a smart, deep, and very unique CRPG, then Fallout is an excellent way to spend $10. If you are coming from the new games to experience the beginning of the franchise, then consider that this game is much more complex and difficult than the newer entries. This is not to discourage, however, as this game is, all in all, a brilliant experience that has proved itself to be a classic in my eyes.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												Fallout 1's story was concise without being simple. Everything that was there needed to be; there was no fluff, no fat, no waste. The quests you undertook were relevant to the main plot and visibly moved the story forward. The villain was appropriately menacing and evil, but his actions made sense. When you asked 'why', he gave you a reasonable answer. The ending was emotionally impactful, not just for your character, but for you - being turned on at the end felt like a punch in the gut, but once again, it made sense. The overall story was a hero's journey, but the plot elements were still unique. Regardless of which game you like best, by artistic standards Fallout 1 the best written narrative in the series hands down.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 14, 2014
												A classic isometric cRPG, set in a post-nuclear war California. The main storyline itself is interesting but short. The best experience you get is from wandering the wasteland, completing side quests, talking to people about their experiences in the wasteland, and getting powerful weapons and armour. Places and towns vary from the bunker of the brotherhood of steel, to the 'Boneyard' (a ruined Los Angeles).The exploration is done differently from the bethesda fallout games. Instead of a continuous world like the elder scrolls games, you travel from place to place on an overhead map, going into real time when you enter areas and towns, or when you encounter enemies, like raiders, super mutants, and other special encounters as you travel across the wasteland. It's different, as it makes the wasteland seem more empty and barren (like a wasteland should be). The range of locations is large, from pristine pre-war vaults, to ruined cities, to gothic cathedrals, making each stop in the game world interesting.Character creation is the most complex in the series, similar to that of pen and paper RPGs. SPECIAL is a system which determines your base stats, which you build upon with a plethora of skills, optional traits (most of which have both a good and bad effect on your build), and perks, which you gain every 3 levels (4 if you have the 'skilled' optional trait), which gives you benefits in different areas. This game depends alot on numbers and stats, so choosing the right build and developing correctly is crucial.  Combat is turn-based, and resembles table-top combat. It's difficult, but you won't be constantly dying. No cover mechanics to be found here. But this doesn't mean the combat isn't complex. Your character build is very important, and your stats influence what kind of approach is best. A high endurance and strength character, who specialises in melee combat, will do well up close, instead of shooting from afar. Aside from that, you have lots of weapons you can use, from shotguns and sniper rifles, to rocket launchers and mini guns. Unlike Fallout 4, which seemingly gives you the power armour quickly for some reason, you can get it through different ways, such as repairing a broken suit, or stealing one, each way requiring you to be part of the brotherhood of steel. On top of that, you can harden your power armour, making it even more durable.Interactions with NPCs are interesting, and tell you more about the wasteland. Your interactions with them are constant. If you insult someone, they won't like you, they won't give you a job or a quest, or may even call on hired guards to kill you. This may seem simple nowadays, but it was cool to have back then. Important NPCs are shown with animated faces, and they can vary from paranoid businessman, to mutant ghouls. Your acts in the wasteland will change your reputation, and this will affect interactions with NPCs, which may lead to certain benefits or disadvantages.The atmosphere in this game is some of the best in a game to date. Gritty, dark, but with a touch of sarcastic and black humour, this game obviously draws influence from films like a boy and his dog, Mad Max, and books like a canticle for Leibowitz. It's art direction draws on from the 1950's vision for the future, with robots looking like something from forbidden planet than from the terminator. The humour is sparse, but well placed in characters like Harold, who despite living in an immortal agony, he can still make a joke or two. The music adds to this, each track a poignant, ambient soundscape of the area you currently, filled with industrial creaks, whining winds, and sudden crashes of metal on metal, emphasising the unforgiving world you must surivive in, instead of constantly hearing about "Butcher Pete", or whoever that is. Unlike Fallout 2, you won't have constant Monty Python references thrown in your face every random encounter, but there are some interesting ones, like a random encounter with the telephone box from doctor who. This game is old (1997), and it shows. The enviroments look nice and detailed, but still have that pixely look. The UI can be confusing and off putting, and things like quests and missions are marked with little detail (e.g. "Find the water chip"), which means you'll have to remember the vital quest details. The combat is VERY slow, but can be sped up in the options, though this won't do much if you have lots of enemies to fight. There's no auto-saving, and you'll need to save often, or when you get killed, you'll have to load a save you made ages back. The inventory isn't amazing, as you'll need to keep clicking down and up arrows to get what you want. Also, thanks to Bethesda, this version of the game is the UK censored edition, removing swearing and other adult themes from the game entirely, as well as a poor port which you need to use patches to fix the resolution. This game is about a nuclear wasteland, where all hope for humanity is gone, mutants roam around killing people, and the only known technological power that isn't killing everyone (The Brotherhood of Steel), won't communicate with the outside world. WHY THE ♥♥♥♥ WOULD YOU REMOVE A BIT OF SWEARING!? If I wanted a family-friendly game, I would play lego star wars. Overall, Fallout is an awesome game. Complex, with alot of custimisation, interactions and exploration, in a very large and dangerous world. However, confusing UI and quest tracking, along with some features some new players may find very annoying, means you'll need to get used it, though it is definitely worth it.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												Some of the best writing I've seen in a videogame. It starts out as a humble quest to save your home, but soon you're out to save what's left of humanity from a fate that's worse than nuclear war. The main antagonist is a the best kind of villain -- not evil for the sake of it, but because he's flawed, he has truly admirable goals and motivations but his methods leave a lot to be desired. I'd say give it a chance. Learn to get past the dated graphics and the turn-based gameplay, and just appreciate the story.

												In my opinion, one of the best games in history. This game defined me as a gamer as a kid, through nothing more than a demo on a disc. I remember the first time I booted this game up, and got blown to bits by bandits because I had the fix idea that I should pickpocket or loot them all. Why one may ask? Well, simple really. I would be damned if I didn't have that awesome looking black uni-sleeved leather jacket!Enter my mother, seeing the splatter, who in turn look at me with a most disgruntled expression before asking me politely what the hell I was doing. Being a wise♥♥♥♥♥ I told her the truth, I was getting myself some better gear!Twenty years later, I'm still brutally blowing♥♥♥♥♥♥to bits for better gear! Safe to say, that Fallout: A Post Nuclear Role Playing Game has created not one, but millions of monsters across the globe with it's brutal humor. Much love.

Posted: November 25, 2016
												Normally when I restart a game every time I launch it, it's because I have no investment in it (as was the case with Sunrider: Mask of Arcadius, where I couldn't even bring myself to finish the opening narration), or it's simply not a game meant to have one playthough happen across multiple sessions (like FTL, or Long Live the Queen). Fallout, however, keeps me coming back consistantly despite how often I decide to try out a new build. It's definitely antiquated, but that shouldn't be a huge problem. If you started the Fallout series with one of the newer games (As I did), then the Isometric camera, turn based combat, and MUCH more open ended gameplay may take a bit of adjusting, but it's definitely worth perservering. If you want to try out an old school western RPG, then this is definitely a great choice.
